{{other uses|Arnaut (disambiguation)}}
[[File:Arnaut-in-Cairo.jpg|thumb|260px|''Arnaut'' in [[Cairo]], a painting by [[Jean-Léon Gérôme]]]]
'''Arnaut''' (ارناود) is a [[Turkish language|Turkish]] [[ethnonym]] used to denote [[Albanians]]. ''Arvanid'' (اروانيد), ''Arnavud'' (آرناوود), plural: ''Arnavudlar'' (آرناوودلار): modern [[Turkish language|Turkish]]: '''''Arnavut''''', plural: ''Arnavutlar''; are ethnoyms used mainly by [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] and contemporary [[Turkish people|Turks]] for Albanians with ''Arnavutça'' being called the [[Albanian language]].<ref name="Theissen90"/><ref name="Anscombe200688"/><ref>"Arnavudca". ''[http://www.osmanlicayazilisi.com/osmanlica-sozluk-madde-39184.html Osmanlıcayazılışı]''. Retrieved 16 January 2016.</ref><ref name="KerslakeGoksel321">{{harvnb|Kerslake|Göksel|2014|pp=321}}.</ref>
==Etymology== These ethnonyms are derived from the Greek term ''[[Arvanites]]'' and entered Turkish after the syllable cluster ''van'' was rearranged through metathesis to ''nav'' giving the final Turkish forms as ''Arnavut'' and ''Arnaut''.<ref name="Theissen90"/><ref name="Malcolm, Noel 1998, p.29">Malcolm, Noel. "Kosovo, a short history". London: Macmillan, 1998, p.29 "The name used in all these references is, allowing for linguistic variations, the same: 'Albanenses' or 'Arbanenses' in Latin, 'Albanoi' or 'Arbanitai' in Byzantine Greek. (The last of these, with an internal switching of consonants, gave rise to the Turkish form 'Arnavud', from which 'Arnaut' was later derived.)"</ref><ref>Ethnic Groups of Europe: An Encyclopedia; Jeffrey E. Cole - 2011, Page 15, "Arbëreshë was the term self-designiation of Albanians before the Ottoman invasion of the 15 century; similar terms are used for Albanian origins populations living in Greece ("Arvanitika," the Greek rendering of Arbëreshë) and Turkey ("Arnaut," Turkish for the Greek term Arvanitika).</ref> Meanwhile, in [[Greek language]] the name ''Arvanitis'' was derived from the original name ''Alvanitis'' [Άλβανίτης] (in return derived from ''Alvanos'' [Άλβάνος]).<ref name="Theissen90"/> The [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Turks]] borrowed their name for Albanians after hearing it from the [[Byzantine Greeks]].<ref name="Malcolm, Noel 1998, p.29"/><ref>Liakos, Antonis. (2012) Hellenisms: culture, identity, and ethnicity from antiquity to modernity. p. 230. "The term "Arvanite" is the medieval equivalent of "Albanian." it is retained today for the descendants of the Albanian tribes that migrated to the Greek lands during a period covering two centuries, from the thirteenth to the fifteenth."</ref>
==Usage== In the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries due to socio-political disturbances by some Albanians in the Balkans the term was used as an ethnic marker for Albanians in addition to the usual [[Millet (Ottoman Empire)|millet]] religious terminology to identify people in Ottoman state records.<ref name="Anscombe200688"/><ref name="Anscombe772"/> While the term used in Ottoman sources for the country was ''Arnavudluk'' (آرناوودلق) for areas such as Albania, Western Macedonia, Southern Serbia, Kosovo, parts of northern Greece and southern Montenegro.<ref name="Anscombe200688">{{harvnb|Anscombe|2006|pp=88}}. "This Albanian participation in brigandage is easier to track than for many other social groups in Ottoman lands, because Albanian (''Arnavud'') was one of the relatively few ethnic markers regularly added to the usual religious (Muslim-Zimmi) tags used to identify people in state records. These records show that the magnitude of banditry involving Albanians grew through the 1770s and 1780s to reach crisis proportions in the 1790s and 1800s."; p.107. "In light of the recent violent troubles in Kosovo and Macedonia and the strong emotions tied to them, readers are urged most emphatically not to draw either of two unwarranted conclusions from this article: that Albanians are somehow inherently inclined to banditry, or that the extent of Ottoman "Albania" or ''Arnavudluk'' (which included parts of present-day northern Greece, western Macedonia, southern Montenegro, Kosovo, and southern Serbia) gives any historical "justification" for the creation of a "Greater Albania" today."</ref><ref name="Anscombe772">{{harvnb|Anscombe|2006b|p=772}}. "In this case, however, Ottoman records contain useful information about the ethnicities of the leading actors in the story. In comparison with 'Serbs', who were not a meaningful category to the Ottoman state, its records refer to 'Albanians' more frequently than to many other cultural or linguistic groups. The term 'Arnavud' was used to denote persons who spoke one of the dialects of Albanian, came from mountainous country in the western Balkans (referred to as 'Arnavudluk', and including not only the area now forming the state of Albania but also neighbouring parts of Greece, Macedonia, Kosovo, and Montenegro), organized society on the strength of blood ties (family, clan, tribe), engaged predominantly in a mix of settled agriculture and livestock herding, and were notable fighters — a group, in short, difficult to control. Other peoples, such as Georgians, Ahkhaz, Circassians, Tatars, Kurds, and Bedouin Arabs who were frequently identified by their ethnicity, shared similar cultural traits."</ref><ref name="Kolovos41">{{harvnb|Kolovos|2007|p=41}}. "Anscombe (ibid., 107 n. 3) notes that Ottoman "Albania" or ''Arnavudluk''... included parts of present-day northern Greece, western Macedonia, southern Montenegro, Kosovo, and southern Serbia"; see also ''El2''. s.v. "Arnawutluk. 6. History" (H. İnalcık) and Arsh, ''He Alvania''. 31.33, 39-40. For the Byzantine period. see Psimouli, ''Souli''. 28."</ref> In modern Turkish ''Arnavutluk'' refers only to the Republic of Albania.<ref name="Emin917">{{harvnb|Emin|2014|pp=9–17}}.</ref> Historically as an exonym the Turkish term ''Arnaut'' has also been used for instance by some Western Europeans as a synonym for Albanians that were employed as soldiers in the Ottoman army.<ref name="Malcolm233">{{harvnb|Malcolm|2009|pp=233}}. "And a further complication is introduced by the term "Arnaut", which could he used as a synonym for "Albanian", hut tended to suggest those Albanians (in the ethnic-linguistic sense) who acted as soldiers for the Ottomans — though these, it should be noted, included Catholic Albanians as well as Muslim ones. (When early reports refer to the local Ottoman forces, such as the force led by Mahmut Begolli [Mehmet Beyoğlu], pasha of Peja, they usually state that they consisted largely of Arnauts. Those Serb historians who claim that the terms Arnaut and Albanian did not mean ethnic Albanians, when applied to the supporters of Piccolomini, seem to have no difficulty in accepting that they did have that meaning, when applied to those fighting against him.)"</ref> The term ''Arnā'ūṭ'' (الأرناؤوط) also entered the [[Arabic]] language as an exonym for Albanian communities that settled in the Levant during the Ottoman era onward, especially for those residing in Syria.<ref name="Norris209210">{{harvnb|Norris|1993|pp=209–210}}</ref> The term ''Arnaut'' (Арнаут), plural: ''Arnauti'' (Арнаути) has also been borrowed into Balkan [[South Slavic languages]] like Bulgarian and within Serbian the term has also acquired pejorative connotations regarding Albanians.<ref>Murati 1991, p. 71. "emri etnik a nacional e shqiptarëve, përkundër trajtës së drejtë sllave Albanci, tash del të shqiptohet si Šiptari e Šipci me një konotacion përbuzës negativ, ashtu siç është përdorur në krye të herës te serbët edhe në kohën e Jugosllavisë së Vjetër bashkë dhe me formën Šiftari e Arnauti me po të njëtat konotacione pejorative. [ethnic name or the national one of Albanians, despite the right Slavic term Albanci, now appears to be pronounced as Šiptari of Šipci with a connotation that is contemptuously negative, as it is used in the very beginning of the Serbs era at the time of the old Yugoslavia together and the form Šiftari and Arnauti which have the same pejorative connotations.]"</ref><ref name="Theissen90">{{harvnb|Theißen|2007|p=90}}. "Der ursprüngliche Name Άλβανίτης (abgeleitet von Άλβάνος) wurde im Neugriechischen zu Άρβανίτης… In türkischer Vermittlung erfuhr die Silbe -''van''- eine Metathese zu -''nav''-, so dass die türkische Form des Namens für die Albaner arnavut bzw. arnaut Lautet. In dieser Form gelangte das Wort ins Bulgarische (BER I/1971: 15). [The original name Άλβανίτης (derived from Άλβάνος) was established in Modern Greek to Άρβανίτης .... In Turkish the syllable was experienced and mediated as -''van''- and by metathesis to -''nav''- so that the Turkish form of the name for the Albanians became respectively Arnavut or Arnaut. In this form, the word came into Bulgarian (BER I / 1971: 15).]"</ref><ref name="Drzavnojstampariji347">{{harvnb|Državnoj štampariji|1878|p=347}}. "зову Арнаут, Арнаутка, па од тог назива доцније им потомци прозову се Арнаутовићи. [...] Арнаучићи зли, пакосни и убојити."</ref>
During the Ottoman era, the name was used for ethnic [[Albanians]] regardless of their religious affiliations, just like it is today.<ref name="Malcolm233"/>
In Ukraine, Albanians who lived in [[Budjak|Budzhak]] and who later also settled in the Azov Littoral of [[Zaporizhia Oblast]] are also known as ''Arnaut''. The city of [[Odessa]] has two streets: ''Great Arnaut Street'' and ''Little Arnaut Street''.<ref name=ethnography>[http://life.pravda.com.ua/travel/2014/05/13/167467/ Seven ethnographical miracles of Ukraine]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. May 13, 2014</ref>

{{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[Freiherr|Baron]] |name = Alexander |honorific-suffix = von Bach |image = Alexander von Bach.jpg |caption = Portrait of Alexander von Bach (c. 1849) by [[Josef Kriehuber]]. |order = |office = Interior Minister of the Austrian Empire |term_start = 28 July 1849 |term_end = 22 August 1859 |monarch = [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Francis Joseph I]] |primeminister = [[Prince Felix of Schwarzenberg]] (1849–1852)
[[Count Karl Ferdinand von Buol]] (1852–1859) |predecessor = [[Franz Stadion, Count von Warthausen]] |successor = [[Count Agenor Gołuchowski]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1813|01|04|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Loosdorf]], Austria |death_date = {{death date and age|1893|11|12|1813|01|04|df=y}} |death_place = [[Schöngrabern]], Austria }} Baron '''Alexander von Bach''' (German: ''Alexander Freiherr{{German title|Freiherr}} von Bach''; 4 January 1813, [[Loosdorf]], Austria - 12 November 1893, [[Schöngrabern]], Austria) was an [[Austrian Empire|Austrian]] politician. His most notable achievement was instituting a system of centralized control at the beginning of the reign of Emperor [[Franz Joseph I of Austria]]. ==Biography== === Early life === Born in Loosdorf, Lower Austria, he came from a legal background, with his father holding a judicial office.{{Cite NIE|wstitle=Bach, Alexander, Baron|year=1905}} At the age of 24 he was made a [[doctor of laws]], and then entered the Imperial service, where he remained for nine years. Seen as an up-and-coming, young radical, [[Adolph Schwarzenberg]] noted that 'his motto must have been "to improvise is to change, to be perfect is to change often"'.Schwarzenberg. A. ''Prince Felix zu Schwarzenberg''. New York: Columbia University Press, 1946. p. 28. In this way, he was a well-known [[Liberalism|liberal]] lawyer, and was first called a "minister of barricades", before he served as Minister of Justice in 1848 and 1849, and then moving on to Minister of the Interior from 1849 to 1859. === Minister of the Interior (1849-1859) === Although he favored a departure from the absolute system of [[Metternich]], Bach was not prepared to go so far as the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas|Revolutionaries of 1848]] wished. In his views, he has been called a man who was 'quite wonderfully unprincipled' and so could change his position often.Crankshaw, E. The Fall of the House of Habsburg. London: Longmans, 1963. p. 138. This allowed him to be driven into conservative ranks by popular opposition: he gradually adhered to [[Conservatism|conservative]] views, endorsing the centralizing constitutional program of [[Prince Felix of Schwarzenberg|Prince Schwarzenberg]] in March 1849, thus further inflaming [[Hungarians|Hungarian]] sentiments.Rothenburg, G. ''The Army of Francis Joseph''. West Lafayette: Purdue University Press, 1976. p 33. However, the impact of his reforms on Hungary has been the contest of many historical debates. Some viewed the Revolution as far more productive in recreating the Hungarian "national identity",Taylor, A. J. P. ''The Habsburg Monarchy: 1809-1918''. London: Hamish Hamilton, 1948. p. 63. whereas some contemporaries of later Hungarian revolutions saw the systems created by Bach as the foremost driver in [[Hungarian nationalism]].‘Magyar Revolution Believed to be Near’. The New York Times. (8 October 1905). After the death of Schwarzenberg in 1852, he largely dictated policy in Austria and [[Hungary]]. Bach centralized administrative authority for the [[Austrian Empire]], but he also endorsed [[reactionary]] policies that reduced [[freedom of the press]] and abandoned public trials. He represented later the [[Enlightened absolutism|Absolutist]] (or ''Klerikalabsolutist'') direction, which culminated in the concordat of August 1855 that gave the [[Roman Catholic Church]] control over education and family life. This period in the history of the Austrian Empire would become known as the era of "neo-absolutism", or [[Bach's absolutism]]. Bach was created [[Baron]] (''Freiherr'') in 1854. He was also the guardian of Science Academy (''Akademie der Wissenschaften'') in 1849–59. === Later life === His fall in 1859 was highly caused by the failure in the Italian war against the [[Kingdom of Sardinia]] and [[Napoleon III]]. His reforms of the military had led to industrialization being foregone to the army, with barracks taking place of factories and infrastructural expansion, weakening.Taylor, A. J. P. op. cit. p. 89. After leaving his position, Bach served as Ambassador to the [[Holy See]] in 1859-1867 before dying in seclusion in 1893. == Notes == {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Macho, Eva, ''Alexander Freiherr von Bach. Stationen einer umstrittenen Karriere'' (Frankfurt am Main u.a., Peter Lang, 2009) (Beiträge zur Neueren Geschichte Österreichs, 24). == External links == * [http://encyklopedie.seznam.cz/heslo/213804-bach-alexander-judr-ministr-rakousky Ottův slovník naučný] {{cs icon}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|before=[[Franz Stadion, Count von Warthausen]]|after=[[Count Agenor Gołuchowski]]|years=1849–1859|title=Interior Minister of the Austrian Empire}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bach, Alexander von}} [[Category:1813 births]] [[Category:1893 deaths]] [[Category:People from Melk District]] [[Category:Austrian politicians]] [[Category:Barons of Austria]] [[Category:People of the Revolutions of 1848]] [[Category:Hungary under Habsburg rule]]

{{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox writer <!--For more information, see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]].--> | name = Bertram Stevens | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Bertram William Mathyson Francis Stevens | birth_date = {{Birth date|1872|10|08|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Inverell, New South Wales]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1922|02|14|1872|10|08|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], Australia | occupation = | language = English | nationality = Australian | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | notableworks = ''[[An Anthology of Australian Verse]]'' | awards = | years_active = 1874-1921 }} '''Bertram William Mathyson Francis Stevens''' (8 October 1872 – 14 February 1922) was Australian journal editor (''Single Tax''; ''Native Companion''; ''Art in Australia''; ''Lone Hand''); literary and art critic; and anthologist (''An Anthology of Australian Verse'' [which contained five poems by [[Henry Lawson]]]; ''The Golden Treasury of Australian Verse'').<ref name=adb>Ken Stewart, '[http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A120090b.htm Stevens, Bertram William Mathyson Francis (1872 - 1922)]', [[Australian Dictionary of Biography]], Volume 12, [[Melbourne University Press|MUP]], 1990, pp 77-78. Retrieved 10 March 2010</ref>
Stevens was born at [[Inverell, New South Wales]], the eldest child of William Mathison Stevens and his wife Marian, ''née'' Cafe, from [[Queanbeyan]].<ref name=adb/> By 1882 Stevens moved with his family to [[Newtown, New South Wales|Newtown]], [[Sydney]] where he was educated at public schools. Stevens was an avid reader and developed a wide knowledge and culture. In 1895 he began a fifteen-year period as a solicitor's clerk and it was intended that he should study law. During this time Stevens worked as a freelance journalist, coming into contact with a number of literary figures, he edited ''My Sundowner and other Poems'' (1904) by [[John Farrell (poet)|John Farrell]] with a memoir. Stevens prepared ''An Anthology of Australian Verse'' (1906), in which he was hampered by copyright restrictions, but he had a much freer hand in ''The Golden Treasury of Australian Verse'' (1909), the first anthology of Australasian verse of any importance. In the same year he had the difficult task of succeeding [[Alfred Stephens]] as editor of the 'Red Page' of ''[[The Bulletin]]''. [[David Scott Mitchell]] gave him access to his library of Australiana.
At the end of 1911 Stevens became editor of the [[Lone Hand (magazine)|Lone Hand]] and conducted this journal for seven years. In 1916 Stevens was one of the founders and joint-editor (with [[Sydney Ure Smith]]) of ''[[Art in Australia]]'' until his death. He also did literary criticism for ''[[The Sydney Mail]]'' and other journals, published editions of Australian poets, prepared other anthologies, and edited books on leading Australian artists. Much of his literary work is listed in Serle's ''Bibliography of Australasian Poetry and Verse'' and Miller's ''Australian Literature''.
Stevens campaigned for the land policies of [[Henry George]], temporarily winning Henry Lawson to the cause. He was a founding member of the [[Dawn and Dusk Club]] in 1899 and of the Casuals Club in 1906.<ref name=adb/> Stevens was deeply involved with attempts at rehabilitating Henry Lawson at [[Yanco, New South Wales]] and [[Edwin Brady]]'s property at [[Mallacoota, Victoria]].
Stevens died suddenly of cerebral haemorrhage and chronic nephritis at Sydney, on 14 February 1922.<ref name=adb/> He left a widow, two sons and a daughter. [[Henry Lawson]] wrote a warm confessional tribute in ''The Bulletin''.<ref name=adb/> At the time of his death he was vice-president of the New South Wales Institute of Journalists. He had been preparing ''A History of Australian Literature'' for some years before his death, but this was never published. Many of his papers are at the [[Mitchell Library (Australia)|Mitchell library]], Sydney.
==Bibliography==
===Poetry anthologies=== * ''[[An Anthology of Australian Verse]]'' (1907) * ''The Australian Birthday Book : Passages Selected from Australia and New Zealand Poetry'' (1908) * ''The Golden Treasury of Australian Verse'' (1909) * ''Selections from the Australian Poets'' (1913) * ''The Children's Treasury of Australian Verse'' (1913) * ''A Book of Australian Verse for Boys and Girls'' (1915) * ''The Australian Soldiers' Gift Book'' (1916) * ''The Bulletin Book of Humorous Verses and Recitations'' (1920)
===Selected work===
* ''My Sundowner and Other Poems'' by [[John Farrell (Australian poet)|John Farrell]] (1904) * ''Wine and Roses'' by [[Victor Daley|Victor J. Daley]] (1911) * ''Oswald Watt, Lieut.-Colonel A.F.C., O.B.E., Legion of Honour, Croix de Guerre : a tribute to his memory by a few of his friends'' edited with Ernest Watt and [[Ure Smith]] (1921)

{{For|the ice hockey player|Brenden Morrow}} {{Infobox baseball biography | name = Brandon Morrow | image = Brandon Morrow on August 5, 2017 (cropped).jpg | width = 250 | caption = Morrow with the Dodgers in 2017 | position = [[Pitcher]] | team = Chicago Cubs | number = 15 | bats = Right | throws = Right | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1984|7|26}} | birth_place = [[Santa Rosa, California]] | debutleague = MLB | debutdate = April 3 | debutyear = 2007 | debutteam = Seattle Mariners | statleague = MLB | statyear = July 15, 2018 | stat1label = [[Win–loss record (pitching)|Win–loss record]] | stat1value = 51–43 | stat2label = [[Earned run average]] | stat2value = 3.96 | stat3label = [[Strikeout]]s | stat3value = 877 | stat4label = [[Walks plus hits per inning pitched|WHIP]] | stat4value = 1.32 | stat5label = [[Save (baseball)|Save]]s | stat5value = 40 | teams = * [[Seattle Mariners]] ({{mlby|2007}}–{{mlby|2009}}) * [[Toronto Blue Jays]] ({{mlby|2010}}–{{mlby|2014}}) * [[San Diego Padres]] ({{mlby|2015}}–{{mlby|2016}}) * [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] ({{mlby|2017}}) * [[Chicago Cubs]] ({{mlby|2018}}–present) | awards = }}
'''Brandon John Morrow''' (born July 26, 1984) is an American [[professional baseball]] [[relief pitcher]] for the [[Chicago Cubs]] of [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB). He previously played for the [[Seattle Mariners]], [[Toronto Blue Jays]], [[San Diego Padres]], and [[Los Angeles Dodgers]]. On August 8, 2010, Morrow pitched a complete game one-hitter with 17 strikeouts, coming within one out of a no-hitter. In the [[2017 World Series]], he became just the second pitcher ever to appear in all seven games of the series.
==Amateur career==
===High school=== Morrow attended [[Rancho Cotate High School]] in [[Rohnert Park, California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/yankees/toronto-blue-jays-pitcher-brandon-morrow-manages-diabetes-routine-faces-new-york-yankees-article-1.463302|title=Toronto Blue Jays pitcher Brandon Morrow manages diabetes with routine, faces New York Yankees|last=Brennan|first=Sean|date=July 4, 2010|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> As a senior, he was 9-2 with a 0.61 ERA and had 84 strikeouts in 63 innings. He earned first-team all-league, first-team All-Redwood Empire, first-team All-North Coast Section and second-team all-state honors, and competed for the California All-Stars at the 2002 Sunbelt Classic in [[McAlester, Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dlife.com/diabetes/famous_people/sports/brandon-morrow-biography|title=Brandon Morrow Biography|publisher=DLife.com|date=November 28, 2012|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
He was selected by the [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|Anaheim Angels]] in the 40th round, 1200th overall, in the [[2003 Major League Baseball Draft]].<ref name="BR Minors">{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=morrow001bra|title=Brandon Morrow Minor League Statistics & History|publisher=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> However, he did not sign with the Angels and decided to attend college at [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]]. He majored in [[American studies]].<ref name="Cal Bears">{{cite web|url=http://www.calbears.com/sports/m-basebl/mtt/brandon_morrow_238203.html|title=Brandon Morrow Bio - The University of California Official Athletic Site|publisher=CalBears.com|accessdate=April 17, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130628203723/http://www.calbears.com/sports/m-basebl/mtt/brandon_morrow_238203.html|archivedate=June 28, 2013|df=}}</ref>
===College=== He attended the University of California. He appeared in 19 games for the Golden Bears with five starts in his freshman year, going 1-3 with a 6.07 ERA and 18 strikeouts in 30 innings. He picked up the win in relief versus the [[University of California Los Angeles]] on April 25 going one inning, surrendering one hit, and striking out two. Morrow had three strikeouts in two innings against [[Brigham Young University]] on January 30.<ref name="Cal Bears"/>
As a sophomore Morrow made ten appearances with five starts, going 0-1 with a 9.36 ERA and one save. He had 25 strikeouts in 25 innings. He earned his lone save on March 19 against the [[University of Hawaii at Hilo]] with three strikeouts in two innings. He threw a career-high five innings with a career-high six strikeouts against [[Loyola Marymount University]] on February 13.<ref name="Cal Bears"/>
Morrow was named first-team All-[[Pac-10]] his junior year, going 7-4 with a 2.05 ERA, second in Pac-10. He had 97 strikeouts, fourth in Pac-10. He held opponents to a .211 average good enough for third in Pac-10. Morrow was named National Pitcher of the Week after pitching seven innings, no hits, no runs, one walk and a career-high 12 strikeouts against [[University of California, Irvine]].<ref name="Cal Bears"/>
He was a [[Cape Cod League]] All-Star in the {{Baseball year|2006}} summer for the [[Yarmouth-Dennis Red Sox]], striking out 24 batters in 15 innings with a 1.84 ERA and three saves. He was named a third-team preseason All-American and the fifth-best professional prospect out of the Cape Cod League by [[Baseball America]].<ref name="Cal Bears"/>
==Professional career==
===Seattle Mariners===
====2006==== In his first professional season in {{Baseball year|2006}} he split time between [[Arizona League Mariners]] appearing in seven games and Single-A [[Inland Empire 66ers]] appearing in one game of the [[California League]]. He posted an 0-2 record overall with a 2.25 ERA in 16 innings striking out 17 batters and starting five games. He pitched three hitless innings for Inland Empire during his brief time there.<ref name="BR Minors"/>
====2007==== [[File:BrandonMorrowField.jpg|200px|thumb|Morrow with the Seattle Mariners in 2007]] Morrow was invited to [[spring training]] in {{mlby|2007}}. He went 0-1 with a 1.08 ERA in 6 [[Relief pitcher|relief]] appearances and made the major league club despite being considered a long-shot to make the club at the start of spring.
Morrow made his Major League debut on April 3 against the [[Oakland Athletics]], pitching one scoreless inning.
Morrow went 3-4, with a 4.12 ERA in 60 appearances striking out 66 batters and walking 50. He held opposing hitters to a .243 batting average, including .221 against right-handed batters. He set a club rookie record with 18 [[hold (baseball)|hold]]s, breaking old record of 13 set by [[Ed Vande Berg]] in {{mlby|1982}}. Morrow had the fourth most appearances by a rookie reliever in club history with 60 and fifth most strikeouts with 66. Among [[American League]] rookie relievers Morrow ranked second in strikeouts, third in appearances and fourth in ERA.
On April 23, he earned his first major league win against the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]], allowing one hit in career-high three and one third innings pitched. He recorded 18 and two thirds consecutive scoreless innings from April 20 to June 8. During the streak he went 2-0 while holding opposing batters to a .103 average. He also recorded another scoreless streak of 17 innings pitched over 15 outings from July 17 to August 24. Morrow held opponents scoreless in 44 of 60 outings.
====2008==== After missing two weeks of spring training in 2008 due to a sore shoulder,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kffl.com/player/15027/MLB|title=Brandon Morrow, SP, Toronto Blue Jays|publisher=KFFL.com|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> Morrow was optioned to the Mariners minor league affiliate Double-A [[West Tenn Diamond Jaxx|West Tennessee]] on March 30. Morrow was recalled to the Seattle bullpen 17 days afterwards when Mariners starter [[Érik Bédard]] was placed on the 15-day [[disabled list]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.seattletimes.nwsource.com/mariners/2008/04/morrow_called_up.html|title=Morrow called up|last=Baker|first=Geoff|publisher=The Seattle Times|date=April 16, 2008|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> When Seattle's regular [[Closer (baseball)|closer]] [[J. J. Putz]] became injured on June 12, Morrow took over his duties. Including a closing appearance on June 11, Morrow [[Save (baseball)|saved]] 8 games in 8 tries, before a July 10 opportunity when he gave up two solo [[home run]]s to the [[Oakland Athletics]] to acquire his first blown save. He had only given up 2 [[Run (baseball)|runs]] all year prior to that, and had 40 strikeouts in 36.2 innings pitched, and a very low ERA of 1.76 and WHIP of 0.88.<ref>{{Cite web|title=ESPN Player Stats|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/players/profile?playerId=28734|accessdate=April 17, 2013|publisher=[[ESPN.com]]}}</ref>
On August 5, Morrow was optioned to Triple-A to become a starting pitcher.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Seattle Weekly: The Bright Spot in an Awful Season|url=http://www.seattleweekly.com/2008-08-13/news/the-bright-spot-in-an-awful-season.php/1|accessdate=August 18, 2008|publisher=[[Seattle Weekly]]}}</ref>
Morrow made his first MLB start on September 5, against the [[New York Yankees]]. Morrow went 7{{fraction|2|3}} [[No-hitter|no-hit]] innings in his first major league start and was 4 outs away to being just the second player to throw a no hitter in their MLB starting debut only to see [[pinch hitter]] [[Wilson Betemit]] end his bid. The Mariners went on to win the game 3-1 giving Morrow his first win as a starter.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Seattle Post-Intelligencer: Morrow's first start for M's will be against Yankees|url=http://blog.seattlepi.nwsource.com/baseball/archives/147185.asp?source=rss|accessdate=August 30, 2008}}</ref>
====2009==== On March 29, {{mlby|2009}} the Mariners announced that Morrow would no longer be used as a [[starting pitcher]]; instead, he would move into a relief role with the organization. Morrow, who has [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|Type 1 diabetes]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/baseball/2012/05/14/blue_jays_brandon_morrow_embraces_being_a_role_model_for_diabetics.html|title=Blue Jays' Brandon Morrow embraces being a role model for diabetics|last=Bailey|first=Sue|agency=[[The Canadian Press]]|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|publisher=Toronto Star Newspapers|date=May 14, 2012|accessdate=April 5, 2013}}</ref> acknowledged that his diabetes was a factor in the decision, saying that it was easier to balance his [[blood sugar]] in a relief position.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/baseball/mlb/03/29/mariners.morrow.ap/index.html|title=Morrow headed to Seattle bullpen|publisher=SI.com|date=March 29, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
Morrow began the season as the [[closer (baseball)|closer]] and earned five saves through the end of April. However, he was placed on the disabled list on May 2 after he developed right biceps tendinitis. [[David Aardsma]] served as closer in his absence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seattle.mariners.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090502&content_id=4533332&vkey=news_sea&fext=.jsp&c_id=sea|title=Mariners closer Morrow lands on DL|last=Street|first=Jim|publisher=MLB.com|date=May 2, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225003253/http://seattle.mariners.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090502&content_id=4533332&vkey=news_sea&fext=.jsp&c_id=sea|archivedate=February 25, 2012|df=}}</ref>
After coming off the disabled list Morrow returned to the starting rotation, making six starts before being optioned to the Triple-A [[Tacoma Rainiers]] to develop back into a more rounded starting pitcher.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seattle.mariners.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090711&content_id=5827214&vkey=news_sea&fext=.jsp&c_id=sea|title=About face: Morrow returns to Minors|last=Street|first=Jim|date=July 11, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
On August 14, Morrow pitched a four hit shutout against the [[Iowa Cubs]]. During that game Morrow struck out two, walked one and threw 59 of 96 pitches for strikes. Morrow retired 10 straight batters early in the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/mariners/2009665621_taco15.html|title=Brandon Morrow throws four-hit shuout for Rainiers|publisher=The Seattle Times|date=August 14, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604094722/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/mariners/2009665621_taco15.html|archivedate=June 4, 2011|df=}}</ref>
Morrow won his fifth consecutive decision for Tacoma tossing five scoreless innings to lead the Rainiers to a 4-1 win over the [[Portland Beavers]] on August 29.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/mariners/2009772436_taco30.html|title=Brandon Morrow wins again for Rainiers|publisher=The Seattle Times|date=August 29, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604094728/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/mariners/2009772436_taco30.html|archivedate=June 4, 2011|df=}}</ref> Morrow was removed from the game because of stiffness in his arm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/mariners/2009776619_marinotes31.html|title=Brandon Morrow has setback at Tacoma|publisher=The Seattle Times|date=August 30, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604094735/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/mariners/2009776619_marinotes31.html|archivedate=June 4, 2011|df=}}</ref>
On September 9, Morrow was called up to the Mariners. He was to start at least one game, so manager [[Don Wakamatsu]] could assess Morrow's progress.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090909&content_id=6880948&vkey=news_sea&fext=.jsp&c_id=sea&partnerId=rss_sea|title=Lacking depth, Mariners summon Morrow|last=Street|first=Jim|publisher=MLB.com|date=September 9, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> On September 30, Morrow gave up one hit and walked two hitters in 8 shutout innings against the [[Oakland Athletics]]. The Mariners won the game 7-0.
===Toronto Blue Jays=== On December 22, 2009, the Mariners traded Morrow to the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] for pitcher [[Brandon League]] and minor league outfielder Johermyn Chávez.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/news/comments.jsp?ymd=20091222&content_id=7841362&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=tor|title=Jays, Mariners to swap League, Morrow|last=Bastian|first=Jordan|date=December 22, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
====2010==== Morrow's first season in Toronto was the first of his major league career as a full-time member of a starting rotation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/sports/baseball/2011/02/25/17412966.html|title=Morrow learning how to pitch - and that's scary|last=Fidlin|first=Ken|publisher=TorontoSun.com|date=February 25, 2011|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> Toronto's coaching staff altered Morrow's delivery in a similar fashion to the way [[Roy Halladay]]'s delivery was altered during his first years with the Blue Jays. The switch from an over-the-top arm motion to a lower-angle arm slot was believed to have contributed to an increased command of his pitches. He was also encouraged to reduce his pitch velocity and try to induce weak contact, again much in the same way Halladay was taught during his tenure in Toronto.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/al/bluejays/2008-05-08-jayshalladay_N.htm?loc=interstitialskip | work=USA Today | first=Paul | last=White | title=Innings-eater Halladay gives Jays bullpen holiday | date=May 9, 2008|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/2011/03/01/morrow_development_davidi/|title=MLB Insider: Secret of Jays' Morrow success|last=Davidi|first=Shi|publisher=SportsNet.ca|date=March 1, 2011|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> Despite some struggles with inconsistency during the early stages of the alterations, statistics show that his production stabilized as the season progressed and he managed to produce favorable results on a regular basis before the end of the season, including a stellar 17 strikeout, one hit performance that was a candidate for MLB.com's [[This Year in Baseball Awards|This Year in Baseball]] Performance of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/awards/y2010/tyib/index.jsp|title=This Year in Baseball Awards|publisher=MLB.com|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:IMG 6637 Brandon Morrow.jpg|left|upright|thumb|Morrow pitching for the Blue Jays in 2011]] On August 8, Morrow was one out away from a [[no-hitter]] against the [[Tampa Bay Rays]] when [[Evan Longoria]] hit an infield single. It would have been the first no-hitter by a Blue Jay since [[Dave Stieb]]'s no-hitter on September 2, 1990.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/mlb/boxscore?gameId=300808114&teams=tampa-bay-rays-vs-toronto-blue-jays|title=Tampa Bay Rays vs. Toronto Blue Jays - Box score - August 8, 2010|publisher=ESPN.com|date=August 8, 2010|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> He finished the one-hitter for his first [[complete game]] while compiling 17 strikeouts, a career high for Morrow in a game and one strikeout shy of the team record 18 strikeouts set by [[Roger Clemens]] in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20100808&content_id=13191556&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=tor|title=Morrow racks up 17 K's, nearly no-hits Rays|last=Bastian|first=Jordan|publisher=MLB.com|date=August 8, 2010|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> According to the [[Game Score]] metric devised by [[Sabremetrics|sabremetrician]] [[Bill James]], this tied for the fourth-highest rated pitching performance since 1920, with a game score of 100.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/statsinfo/post/_/id/4786/no-hitting-is-such-sweet-morrow|title=Near no-hitting is such sweet Morrow|publisher=ESPN.com|date=August 8, 2010|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
On August 29, the Blue Jays announced that after his next start, Morrow would be shut down for the season to protect his arm. He pitched more innings in 2010 (146⅓) than in any of his previous seasons. He finished the season with a 10–7 record, 4.49 ERA, and 178 strikeouts. Morrow was nominated as one of 2010's "Ten People Making a Difference in Diabetes".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2011/01/prweb4950574.htm|title=dLife Top 10 Awards Honor Those Making a Difference in Diabetes|publisher=prweb.com|date=January 11, 2011|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
====2011==== Morrow, who was expected to be the Jays' No. 2 starter in the pitching rotation, began the season on the 15-day disabled list with right forearm inflammation. He made his regular-season debut on April 23 against the [[Tampa Bay Rays]], pitching 5⅓ innings, giving up 3 hits, 2 runs, 2 walks and 10 strikeouts.
For the first time since being traded, Morrow returned to the home stadium of his former team, the Seattle Mariners, to start against them on August 17. Morrow recorded the win, pitching 6 innings and striking out 12 batters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/mlb/gameday/index.jsp?gid=2011_08_17_tormlb_seamlb_1&mode=recap&c_id=tor|title=Morrow's dozen K's keep Mariners at bay|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|publisher=MLB.com|date=August 18, 2011|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
Morrow became the first pitcher in major league history to pitch 100 innings in one season without the team recording a double play behind him.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Zwolinski | first = Mark | title = Baseball Notes: Call It One | newspaper = [[Toronto Star]] |page=S6 | date = August 20, 2011}}</ref> On September 23, after 173⅓ innings dating back to August 28, 2010, [[Desmond Jennings]] of the [[Tampa Bay Rays]] grounded into Morrow's first double play in 30 starts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/mlb/gameday/index.jsp?gid=2011_09_23_tormlb_tbamlb_1&mode=recap&c_id=tor|title=Morrow deals blow to Rays' playoff chances|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|publisher=MLB.com|date=September 23, 2011|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> It would end up being Morrow's only double play induced in the season, but also the only double play Jennings would ground into all season. Morrow finished the season with an 11–11 record, 4.79 ERA, and 203 strikeouts. He led the league in strikeouts over 9 innings with 10.2.
====2012==== On May 3, in a game against the [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim]], Morrow threw a three-hit complete game shutout. The following night, teammate [[Henderson Álvarez]] also threw a complete game shutout. Morrow and Álvarez thus became the first Blue Jays starters to throw back-to-back shutouts since [[Jack Morris]] and [[Al Leiter]] did so on June 16 and 17, 1993.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/mlb/gameday/index.jsp?gid=2012_05_04_tormlb_anamlb_1#gid=2012_05_04_tormlb_anamlb_1&mode=recap&c_id=tor|title=Alvarez deals Toronto's second straight shutout|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|publisher=MLB.com|date=May 5, 2012|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> Morrow established a career high in complete games and shutouts (with 2 each) on May 19, throwing a three-hit shutout against the [[New York Mets]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsn.ca/mlb/story/?id=396345|title=Morrow throws complete game shutout, Blue Jays blank Mets|publisher=TSN.ca|date=May 19, 2012|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> He improved that mark on June 6 against the [[Chicago White Sox]], throwing a complete game two-hit shutout. His third shutout of the season gave him the league lead at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsn.ca/mlb/story/?id=397816|title=Morrow pitches two-hit shutout, Blue Jays beat White Sox|publisher=TSN.ca|date=June 6, 2012|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
Morrow experienced "stabbing pain" during the first inning of his June 11 start while pitching to [[Bryce Harper]], the second hitter in the [[Washington Nationals]] lineup. After delivering three pitches to Harper, Morrow left the game with a strain of the left oblique muscles. No timetable was given for Morrow's return to the rotation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washington.nationals.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120611&content_id=33144022&vkey=news_tor&c_id=tor|title=Morrow strains oblique, will undergo tests|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|publisher=MLB.com|date=June 11, 2012|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref> Morrow returned from the 60-day disabled list on August 25.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120824&content_id=37265428&notebook_id=37299564&vkey=notebook_tor&c_id=tor|title=Hechavarria, Gose sent down to Triple-A|work=MLB.com|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|date=August 24, 2012|accessdate=August 25, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311070218/http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120824&content_id=37265428&notebook_id=37299564&vkey=notebook_tor&c_id=tor#|archive-date=2014-03-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In 124⅔ innings, he finished the season with a 10–7 record, 2.96 ERA, and 103 strikeouts.
====2013==== On February 5, 2013, manager [[John Gibbons]] named Morrow the number 2 starter for the upcoming season, behind reigning NL Cy Young Award winner [[R.A. Dickey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20130205&content_id=41426288&notebook_id=41426816&vkey=notebook_tor&c_id=tor|title=Blue Jays set rotation around No. 1 Dickey|last=Toman|first=Chris|publisher=MLB.com|date=February 5, 2013|accessdate=February 5, 2013}}</ref> After opening the season with a 2–3 record and a 5.63 earned run average, Morrow was placed on the 15-day disabled list on June 1 with a right forearm strain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20130601&content_id=49290930&vkey=news_tor&c_id=tor|title=Morrow lands on DL with forearm strain|last=Berry|first=Adam|publisher=MLB.com|date=June 1, 2013|accessdate=June 1, 2013}}</ref> He made his first rehab start at High-A Dunedin on June 17, and pitched just 2 innings. On June 18, it was announced that Morrow had been pulled from rehabilitation after suffering an unnamed setback during his start.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsn.ca/mlb/story/?id=425793|title=Blue Jays' Morrow suffers setback in Single-A rehab start|publisher=TSN.ca|date=June 18, 2013|accessdate=June 18, 2013}}</ref> An MRI that day revealed only inflammation, and no structural damage in Morrow's arm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20130619&content_id=51143674&notebook_id=51143530&vkey=notebook_tor&c_id=tor|title=No structural damage to Morrow's forearm|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|publisher=MLB.com|date=June 19, 2013|accessdate=June 19, 2013}}</ref>
On July 24, it was reported by [[Rogers Sportsnet]] that Morrow was diagnosed with an entrapped radial nerve in his right forearm, and would likely miss the rest of the 2013 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/toronto-blue-jays-pitcher-brandon-morrow-done-for-the-season-entrapped-radial-nerve/|title=Source: Jays' Morrow likely done for the season|last=Davidi|first=Shi|publisher=Sportsnet.ca|date=July 25, 2013|accessdate=July 25, 2013}}</ref> Blue Jays management said the following day that they expected Morrow to pitch again in 2013, either in late September or in October's instructional league in Florida.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/blue-jays-expect-morrow-to-pitch-again-this-year/|title=Blue Jays expect Morrow to pitch again in 2013|last=Davidi|first=Shi|publisher=Sportsnet.ca|date=July 25, 2013|accessdate=July 25, 2013}}</ref> Manager John Gibbons later said on August 22 that Morrow would remain on the disabled list for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsn.ca/mlb/story/?id=430268|title=MacArthur: Morrow out for season; Cabrera unlikely to return|last=MacArthur|first=Scott|publisher=TSN.ca|date=August 22, 2013|accessdate=August 22, 2013}}</ref> In 2013, Morrow posted a record of 2–3, a 5.63 earned run average, and 41 strikeouts over just 54{{frac|1|3}} innings pitched.
====2014==== Morrow struggled throughout early spring training, giving up 7 earned runs through just 8 innings pitched. On March 18, manager John Gibbons confirmed that Morrow would be the team's fifth starter, citing a need to give him more time to prepare for the regular season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsn.ca/mlb/story/?id=446628|title=Blue Jays manager Gibbons confirms Morrow as fifth starter|work=TSN.ca|date=March 18, 2014|accessdate=March 18, 2014}}</ref> After struggling to open the season, including a start on April 26 where he walked 8 Red Sox batters over 2{{frac|2|3}} innings, Morrow was placed on the 15-day disabled list on May 3 with a sprained right index finger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/baseball/brandon-morrow-put-on-dl-by-blue-jays-santos-out-as-closer-1.2631189|title=Brandon Morrow put on DL by Blue Jays, Santos out as closer|last=Harrison|first=Doug|work=CBC.ca|date=May 3, 2014|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> Later that day his injury was determined to be a more severe torn tendon sheath in his right hand, and he was transferred to the 60-day DL.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/blue-jays-place-rhp-morrow-on-disabled-list/|title=Blue Jays place Morrow on 60-day DL|last=Davidi|first=Shi|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=May 3, 2014|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> Morrow made his first rehab appearance on August 27 with the [[Dunedin Blue Jays]], pitching one scoreless inning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20140827&content_id=91707222&notebook_id=91812468&vkey=notebook_tor&c_id=tor|title=Morrow tosses scoreless frame in rehab outing|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|work=MLB.com|date=August 27, 2014|accessdate=August 29, 2014}}</ref> He was activated from the 60-day DL and added to the Blue Jays active roster on September 1, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/pompey-tweets-hes-been-called-up-by-jays/|title=Pompey, Norris among 9 called up by Blue Jays|last=Davidi|first=Shi|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=September 1, 2014|accessdate=September 1, 2014}}</ref> On November 1, the Blue Jays declined Morrow's $10 million 2015 option, making him a free agent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jaysjournal.com/2014/11/01/blue-jays-decline-options-dustin-mcgowan-brandon-morrow/|title=Blue Jays Decline Options on Dustin McGowan, Brandon Morrow|last=Matheson|first=Keegan|work=jaysjournal.com|date=November 1, 2014|accessdate=November 1, 2014}}</ref>
===San Diego Padres=== On December 16, 2014, Morrow signed a 1-year, $2.5 million contract with the [[San Diego Padres]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/report-padres-agree-to-sign-brandon-morrow/|title=Padres, Brandon Morrow agree to one-year deal|last=Nicholson-Smith|first=Ben|work=[[Sportsnet]]|date=December 16, 2014|accessdate=August 8, 2015}}</ref> He made 5 starts with the Padres in 2015, posting a 2.73 ERA and 23 strikeouts, before going on the disabled list with right shoulder inflammation in early May.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mlb/story/_/id/12829556/san-diego-padres-place-brandon-morrow-disabled-list-ailing-shoulder|title=Padres place Brandon Morrow on DL with shoulder inflammation|work=espn.go.com|date=May 6, 2015|accessdate=August 8, 2015}}</ref> He remained on the disabled list into August, when it was determined that he required season-ending surgery to correct a shoulder impingement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2015/08/08/brandon-morrow-will-undergo-season-ending-shoulder-surgery/|title=Brandon Morrow will undergo season-ending shoulder surgery|last=Baer|first=Bill|work=hardballtalk.nbcsports.com|date=August 8, 2015|accessdate=August 8, 2015}}</ref> On December 17, Morrow signed a minor league contract with the Padres that included an invitation to spring training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/fantasy/baseball/news/padres-brandon-morrow-signs-nri-deal-with-padres/|title=Padres' Brandon Morrow: Signs NRI deal with Padres|work=cbssports.com|date=December 17, 2015|accessdate=December 18, 2015}}</ref>
===Los Angeles Dodgers=== On January 25, 2017, Morrow signed a minor-league contract with the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] that included an invitation to major league spring training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/dodgers/la-sp-dodgers-brandon-morrow-20170125-story.html|title=Dodgers sign reliever Brandon Morrow to minor league deal|work=LA Times|first=Andy|last=McCullough|date=January 25, 2017|accessdate=January 26, 2017}}</ref> He did not make the major league team and was assigned to the Triple-A [[Oklahoma City Dodgers]] to begin the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.milb.com/okc-dodgers/news/okc-dodgers-release-2017-opening-day-roster/c-222441954/t-196093382|title=OKC Dodgers Release 2017 Opening Day Roster|work=milb.com|author=Oklahoma City Dodgers|date=April 5, 2017|accessdate=April 5, 2017}}</ref> Morrow was called up by the Dodgers on May 29, due to a clause in his contract that would have forced the Dodgers to waive him if he wasn't called up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.dodgers.mlb.com/news/article/233098588/dodgers-select-contract-of-brandon-morrow/|title=Dodgers select contract of Brandon Morrow|work=MLB.com|date=May 29, 2017|accessdate=May 29, 2017}}</ref> By the end of the season, Morrow had settled into a role as the Dodgers' [[setup man]]. In 45 appearances out of the Dodgers bullpen, he was 6–0 with a 2.06 ERA with 50 strikeouts and two saves.<ref name=Mbr>{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/morrobr01.shtml|title=Brandon Morrow Statistics & History|work=Baseball Reference|accessdate=November 2, 2017}}</ref>
Morrow allowed one run in 3{{fraction|2|3}} innings in the [[2017 NLDS]], zero runs in 4{{fraction|2|3}} innings in the [[2017 NLCS]] and five runs in 5{{fraction|1|3}} innings in the [[2017 World Series]].<ref name=Mbr/> He was only the second person in history to pitch in all seven games of the World Series.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.truebluela.com/2017/11/1/16594434/yu-darvish-terrible-dodgers-offense-mia-world-series-game-7-recap-29-years|title=Yu Darvish, Dodgers fall short in Game 7|work=SB Nation|first=Eric|last=Stephen|date=November 1, 2017|accessdate=November 2, 2017}}</ref>
===Chicago Cubs=== On December 12, 2017, Morrow signed a two-year, $21-million contract with the [[Chicago Cubs]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://chicago.suntimes.com/sports/cubs-finalize-brandon-morrow-deal-add-lhp-drew-smyly-with-eye-on-19/|title=Cubs finalize Brandon Morrow deal, add LHP Drew Smyly with eye on '19|work=Chicago Sun Times|first=Gordon|last=Wittenmeyer|date=December 12, 2017|accessdate=December 13, 2017}}</ref>
On June 20, 2018, Morrow was placed on the 10-day disabled list due to back tightness.<ref>{{cite web |title=Brandon Morrow goes on DL with back tightness |url=https://www.mlb.com/news/back-tightness-puts-cubs-brandon-morrow-on-dl/c-282098978 |publisher=MLB |accessdate=June 20, 2018}}</ref>
==Pitching style== Morrow throws a hard [[Four-seam fastball|fastball]] which sits between 92 and 100 mph. He has the ability to throw several off-speed pitches, including a [[slider]] (85–89 mph), [[curveball]] (81–85 mph), and [[change-up]] (81–87 mph).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://60ft6in.com/al-east/toronto-blue-jays|title=Pitcher Scouting Reports - Toronto Blue Jays|publisher=60ft6in.com|accessdate=April 17, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017124702/http://60ft6in.com/al-east/toronto-blue-jays/|archivedate=October 17, 2012|df=}}</ref> In September 2011, Morrow debuted a new cut fastball which comes from making a slight adjustment on his slider, with velocity hovering around 88–91 mph.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.bluejays.mlb.com/mlb/gameday/index.jsp?gid=2011_09_18_nyamlb_tormlb_1&mode=recap&c_id=tor|title=Morrow, Lind power Blue Jays past Yankees|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|publisher=MLB.com|date=September 18, 2011|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
==Personal life== Morrow is 6'3" tall and weighs 195 pounds. He is married.<ref>[http://mlb.mlb.com/team/player.jsp?player_id=453344 MLB.com Bio]</ref> His favorite pitcher growing up was [[Pedro Martínez]].<ref>[http://www.tacomaweekly.com/sports/archived/qa_with_brandon_morrow/ Tacoma Weekly interview with Brandon Morrow]</ref>
Morrow has Type 1 diabetes who was diagnosed as a senior in high school. He wears an [[insulin pump]] to regulate his [[blood sugar]] levels.<ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=4034892 Seattle Mariners Pitchers Deal with Diabetes] ESPN, April 2, 2009</ref>

{{Other people}} {{Infobox basketball biography | name = Brian Grant | image = | width = | caption = | number = 33, 44, 55 | position = [[Power forward (basketball)|Power forward]] / [[Center (basketball)|Center]] | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 9 | weight_lb = 254 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|03|05}} | birth_place = [[Columbus, Ohio]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | high_school = [[Georgetown High School (Ohio)|Georgetown]] ([[Georgetown, Ohio]]) | college = [[Xavier Musketeers men's basketball|Xavier]] (1990–1994) | draft_year = 1994 | draft_round = 1 | draft_pick = 8 | draft_team = [[Sacramento Kings]] | career_start = 1994 | career_end = 2006 | years1 = {{nbay|1994|start}}–{{nbay|1996|end}} | team1 = [[Sacramento Kings]] | years2 = {{nbay|1997|start}}–{{nbay|1999|end}} | team2 = [[Portland Trail Blazers]] | years3 = {{nbay|2000|start}}–{{nbay|2003|end}} | team3 = [[Miami Heat]] | years4 = {{nbay|2004|full=y}} | team4 = [[Los Angeles Lakers]] | years5 = {{nbay|2005|full=y}} | team5 = [[Phoenix Suns]] | highlights = * [[NBA All-Rookie First Team]] ({{nbay|1994|end}}) * [[J. Walter Kennedy Citizenship Award]] ({{nbay|1998|end}}) * 2× [[Horizon League Men's Basketball Player of the Year|Horizon League Player of the Year]] (1993, 1994) * No. 33 [[Xavier Musketeers men's basketball#Retired jerseys|retired by Xavier]] | stats_league = NBA | stat1label = [[Point (basketball)|Points]] | stat1value = 7,933 (10.5 ppg) | stat2label = [[Rebound (basketball)|Rebounds]] | stat2value = 5,622 (7.4 rpg) | stat3label = [[Assist (basketball)|Assists]] | stat3value = 923 (1.2 apg) | bbr = grantbr01 }} '''Brian Wade Grant''' (born March 5, 1972) is a retired American [[basketball]] player. He played the [[power forward (basketball)|power forward]] and [[Center (basketball)|center]] positions for five teams during 12 seasons in the [[National Basketball Association]]. He was known for his tenacious [[rebound (basketball)|rebounding]] and blue-collar defense. During his career, he played with the [[Sacramento Kings]] (where he made First Team All-Rookie in the [[1994–95 NBA season|1994–95 season]]), [[Portland Trail Blazers]], [[Miami Heat]], [[Los Angeles Lakers]] and [[Phoenix Suns]].
==Early life== Grant grew up in the small, rural community of [[Georgetown, Ohio]], near the [[Ohio River]] about 40 miles southeast of [[Cincinnati]]. During summers, he spent most of his time working at area farms, cutting, housing, and stripping tobacco, digging potatoes and baling hay. He played basketball at [[Georgetown High School (Ohio)|Georgetown High School]],<ref name="newsdemocrat.com">{{cite web|url=http://newsdemocrat.com/news/sports/2947801/Gtown-holds-Black-and-Gold-Night |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328010640/http://newsdemocrat.com/news/sports/2947801/Gtown-holds-Black-and-Gold-Night |archivedate=2014-03-28 |df= }}</ref> mostly in anonymity until [[Xavier University (Cincinnati)|Xavier University]]'s basketball office began receiving anonymous calls stating that they should take a look at Grant. Xavier assistant coach [[Dino Gaudio]] finally scouted Grant, followed by visits from XU head coach [[Pete Gillen]].<ref name="xtra.xavier.edu">{{cite web|url=http://xtra.xavier.edu/xavier-magazine/brian-grant-a-new-life/|title=Brian Grant - Xavier Magazine|author=|date=|website=xtra.xavier.edu|accessdate=24 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170622011025/http://xtra.xavier.edu/xavier-magazine/brian-grant-a-new-life/|archivedate=22 June 2017|df=}}</ref> Georgetown High's gymnasium has since been renamed Brian Grant Gymnasium.<ref name="newsdemocrat.com"/>
==College career== Grant played basketball at Xavier University, but the anonymity quickly faded. After four seasons at Xavier, Grant was second on the all-time leading scorers' list with 1,719 points. He was twice named [[Midwest Collegiate Conference]] Player of the Year. All four seasons at Xavier he led the Musketeers in rebounding, and was third on the all-time leading rebounding list with 1,080. He was named to the [[Associated Press]] honorable mention All-American team in his junior year, after ranking second in the nation in field goal percentage with 65.4 percent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/xavi/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/2012-13/misc_non_event/12-13-mbb-guide-records.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327203930/http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/xavi/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/2012-13/misc_non_event/12-13-mbb-guide-records.pdf |archivedate=2014-03-27 |df= }}</ref>
He was inducted into the Xavier Athletic Hall of Fame in 1999 and became one of only four basketball players to have his jersey retired, in a ceremony held in 2011.<ref name="xtra.xavier.edu"/>
== NBA career ==
===Sacramento Kings=== Grant was selected in the first round, eighth overall, in the [[1994 NBA draft]] by the Sacramento Kings. In his rookie season he started in 59 out of 80 games, averaging 13.2 points a game with 7.5 rebounds. The following year, he started in 75 out of 78 games, increasing his scoring average to 14.4 points a game as the Kings made the playoffs. The Kings lost in four games to the top-seeded [[1995–96 Seattle SuperSonics season|Seattle SuperSonics]] in the [[1996 NBA Playoffs|first round]], with Grant averaging 9.8 points per game for the series. He signed a five-year, $29 million contract, but due to injuries appeared in only 24 games in the 1996–1997 season, and the Kings did not make the playoffs.
===Portland Trail Blazers=== Grant opted out of the deal following the 1997 season to sign a six-year, $56 million deal with the [[1997–98 Portland Trail Blazers season|Portland Trail Blazers]]. In his first year with the Trail Blazers he started in 49 of 61 games as the team made the playoffs but lost in the [[1998 NBA Playoffs|first round]] to the [[1997–98 Los Angeles Lakers season|Los Angeles Lakers]] 3 games to 1. Grant averaged 13.2 points and 10.7 rebounds a game for the series. The 1998–1999 season was shortened to 50 games because of a league lockout, and Grant started 46 of 48 games with a scoring average of 11.5 points a game and a team high 9.8 rebounds per game. The Trail Blazers won the Pacific Division, swept the [[1998–99 Phoenix Suns season|Phoenix Suns]] in the first round of the [[1999 NBA Playoffs|playoffs]] and defeated the previous Western Conference Champion [[1998–99 Utah Jazz season|Utah Jazz]] in six games in the second round. In the Western Conference Finals, the Trail Blazers were swept by the league-leading [[1998–99 San Antonio Spurs season|San Antonio Spurs]]. Grant started all 13 playoff games and averaged 13.2 points with 9.2 rebounds.
Prior to the 1999–2000 season, Portland acquired veteran all-star [[Scottie Pippen]], and coach [[Mike Dunleavy, Sr.|Mike Dunleavy]] decided to use Grant as a reserve behind rising all-star [[Rasheed Wallace]], who would go on to have a career year during the season as the Trail Blazers won 59 games and the second seed in the Western Conference. Portland opened the [[2000 NBA Playoffs|playoffs]] with a 3-1 first-round win over the [[1999–2000 Minnesota Timberwolves season|Minnesota Timberwolves]], with Grant and Wallace both being used as defensive options against [[Kevin Garnett]]. Grant was used in a similar fashion against [[Karl Malone]] and the [[1999–2000 Utah Jazz season|Utah Jazz]] in the second round, with Portland advancing in five games. In the Western Conference Finals, the Trail Blazers faced the [[1999–2000 Los Angeles Lakers season|Los Angeles Lakers]] led by Pippen's former [[Chicago Bulls]] coach [[Phil Jackson]] and the duo of [[Shaquille O'Neal]] and [[Kobe Bryant]]. The teams split the first two games before the Lakers took games 3 and 4 to take a 3–1 series lead, but Portland responded with a win on the road in game 5 and a home win in the sixth game to set up a seventh game with a trip to the [[NBA Finals]] on the line. Despite taking a double-digit lead into the fourth quarter, the Lakers rallied and won the game, eliminating Portland. Grant averaged 5.4 points and 5.8 rebounds throughout the 2000 playoff run.
After two years as the starting PF and one year as the Blazers' number one big man off the bench, Grant once again opted out of his deal to become a free agent, hoping to land a starting job elsewhere.
===Miami Heat=== In the summer of 2000 Grant signed a 7-year $86 million deal with the [[2000–01 Miami Heat season|Miami Heat]], despite coming off season averages of 7.5 ppg and 5.5 rpg. The deal raised eyebrows, but Heat President and GM [[Pat Riley]] insisted that Grant was the missing piece to the Heat's championship puzzle, along with other recently acquired players [[Eddie Jones (basketball)|Eddie Jones]] and [[Anthony Mason (basketball)|Anthony Mason]]. Weeks before the start of the season Miami's all-star center [[Alonzo Mourning]] was diagnosed with a rare kidney disease forcing Riley to play Grant at center despite usually playing at the power forward position. Grant responded by putting up a career season of 15.2 ppg, 8.8 rpg, and a career high 79.7% at the foul line. Miami won 50 games, and Mourning returned to the team in late March, but were swept in the [[2001 NBA Playoffs|first round]] by the younger [[2000–01 Charlotte Hornets season|Charlotte Hornets]]. Grant averaged 10 points and 8 rebounds for the series.
In the 2001–2002 season, with the anticipated return of Mourning to the lineup, Grant returned to his natural power forward position. Grant started in 72 games for Miami averaging 9.3 points and 8 rebounds a game for the season, but the Heat failed to reach the [[2002 NBA Playoffs|postseason]]. The next year signaled a rebuilding era for the team, as the Heat won just 25 games with Grant averaging 10.3 points a game along with a career high 10.2 rebounds, which placed him at fifth in the league in rebounds per game. He also finished the season 4th in total rebounds, 5th in defensive rebounds, and 10th in the league in field goal percentage at .509 percent, all personal bests. The Heat once again found themselves in the lottery, and would select [[Dwyane Wade]] in the draft to join sophomore [[Caron Butler]] before acquiring free agent [[Lamar Odom]] in the offseason. Alonzo Mourning, who did not play in the 2003 season, left the team and signed with the [[2003–04 New Jersey Nets season|New Jersey Nets]], leaving Grant as the team's best option at the center position. Just prior to the 2003–2004 season, another major franchise change occurred, as Pat Riley stepped down as coach. He would be replaced by longtime assistant [[Stan Van Gundy]].
The 2003–2004 season proved to be a major success for the rebuilding franchise, as the Heat overcame an 0-7 start to eventually make the playoffs as the 4th seed in the East led by the play of Odom, Jones and Wade. Grant started 76 games at center and averaged 8.7 points and 6.9 rebounds a game. In the [[2004 NBA Playoffs|playoffs]], the Heat defeated the [[2003–04 New Orleans Hornets season|New Orleans Hornets]], who had relocated from Charlotte, in a challenging 7 game series in which the home team won every game. In the second round the Heat faced the top seeded [[2003–04 Indiana Pacers season|Indiana Pacers]], who took the first two games in Indiana before the Heat won two straight games at home to tie the series at two games apiece, including a game three victory led by Grant`s 16 rebounds. The Pacers would win the next two games to advance however, defeating the young Heat team considered to have much promise heading into the future. Grant averaged 7.1 points and 8.6 rebounds a game throughout the postseason.
===Los Angeles Lakers and Phoenix Suns=== During the summer of 2004, the Heat traded Grant (along with [[Caron Butler]], [[Lamar Odom]], and a future first-round draft pick) to the Los Angeles Lakers in exchange for superstar [[Shaquille O'Neal]]. Grant would play one year for the rebuilding Lakers, playing in a total of 69 games and starting in 8 with career low averages of 3.8 points and 3.7 rebounds a game. That off-season Grant was released and signed with the Phoenix Suns. He would go on to only appear in 21 games for the Suns, including 5 games in their playoff run which resulted in wins against the Lakers, and the [[2005–06 Los Angeles Clippers season|Los Angeles Clippers]] before falling to the [[2005–06 Dallas Mavericks season|Dallas Mavericks]] in the Western Finals. Following the season Grant was traded in the [[2006 NBA draft]] to the [[2006–07 Boston Celtics season|Boston Celtics]] with the rights to [[Rajon Rondo]] in exchange for a future first-round draft pick. After being waived by the Celtics on October 27, 2006, Grant formally announced his retirement after lingering injuries had reduced his level of play for several seasons.
He is nicknamed "The General" after growing up in the same town of [[Georgetown, Ohio]], as [[American Civil War|Civil War]] [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] general and President [[Ulysses S. Grant]].
Brian worked with [[Greg Oden]] in the 2009 off-season in Columbus, Ohio, for the purposes of adding more toughness, basketball smarts, and miscellaneous advice.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://blog.oregonlive.com/behindblazersbeat/2009/07/brian_grant_toughening_up_greg.html | work=The Oregonian | title=Brian Grant toughening up Greg Oden | date=July 23, 2009 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090726041736/http://blog.oregonlive.com/behindblazersbeat/2009/07/brian_grant_toughening_up_greg.html | archivedate=July 26, 2009 | df= }}</ref>
==Personal life== Grant is the father of seven: sons Amani, Elijah, Jaydon, Jonavan, and Brian; and daughters Maliah and Anaya.
===Charity work=== Brian Grant is well known for his contributions to the communities in various cities. Grant served as the Oregon and Southwest Washington spokesperson for Ronald McDonald House Charities when he was with the Portland Trail Blazers. Grant and Ronald McDonald House Charities teamed up in July 1999 to hold "Brian's Bash" – a celebrity golf tournament in Portland – to raise money for seriously and terminally ill children.
During his time as an NBA player, he started his own foundation in order to assist seriously ill children, as well as their families, and under-privileged youth. These numerous acts of selflessness and generosity were recognized by the NBA in 1999 when he was awarded the J. Walter Kennedy Citizenship Award. A few of the programs that The Brian Grant Foundation has launched are the "Scholastic Attendance Program", the "Christmas Adopt-A-Family Program", the "Thanksgiving Dinner Distribution Program" with Pazzo's Restaurant, Mother's Against Gang Violence, the TLC Soup Kitchen, and the "Brian Grant Free Summer Basketball Clinics" in Portland, Oregon, and Georgetown, Ohio.<ref>http://google.com/search?q=cache:1iVXFNghh_sJ:www.brianbergerpr.com/ar_bg_exec_dir.html+brian+grant+foundation&cd=2&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
After retiring from the NBA and moving his family back to his adopted hometown of Portland, Oregon, Grant was diagnosed with Parkinson's Disease in November 2008. With new friends in Michael J. Fox and Muhammad Ali, who share the disease with Brian, he decided to recreate the Brian Grant Foundation; this time, with a new focus and mission. The new charity supports efforts toward the education and awareness of Parkinson's disease in order to increase earlier diagnosis, educate patients and their families, and provide a viable forum for people affected by the disease. The mission of the foundation is to help those impacted by Parkinson's to live active and fulfilling lives.The foundation hosts an annual fundraiser, Shake It Till We Make It, to raise money to provide support and resources for all those affected by Parkinson's disease. Shake It Till We Make It is a two-day celebrity gala and golf tournament hosted in Portland, Oregon.
The Brian Grant Foundation partners up with other foundations, such as the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research and the Muhammad Ali Parkinson Center, to support and fund research dedicated to finding a cure for Parkinson's disease and to finding improved therapies for people living with Parkinson's disease.
===Health=== In November 2005, after talking with a neurologist at [[OHSU]], Brian Grant was diagnosed with early-onset [[Parkinson's disease]]. Through discussions and encouragement by well-known Parkinson's sufferers [[Michael J. Fox]] and [[Muhammad Ali]], Grant publicized his diagnosis in 2009.<ref name="parkisons-diagnosis">{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/otl/news/story?id=4174877 |title=Former NBA star Brian Grant deals with diagnosis of Parkinson's disease |author=[[Ric Bucher]] |work=[[ESPN.com]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61AMJw7XF?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/otl/news/story?id=4174877 |archivedate=2011-08-24 |df= }}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=June 2015}} In [[Manx folklore]], a {{Lang|gv|'''buggane'''}} (or ''boagane'')<ref>Spelling used in ''[[The Deemster]]''</ref> was a huge [[ogre]]-like creature native to the [[Isle of Man]]. Some have considered them akin to the [[Scandinavia|Scandinavian]] [[troll]].
==Manx folklore== [[File:The medieval chapel of St. Trinian's, near Crosby - geograph.org.uk - 58337.jpg|thumb|Roofless St. Trinian's]] A [[shapeshifting|shapeshifter]], the buggane's natural form is described as "covered with a mane of coarse, black hair; it had eyes like torches, and glittering sharp tusks".<ref name=Morrison>[http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/fulltext/sm1911/index.htm Morrison, Sophia. ''Manx Fairy Tales'', David Nutt, London, 1911]</ref> ===St Trinian's Church=== {{main|St Trinian's Church}} The most famous story recounts a buggane who found himself an inadvertent stowaway on a ship bound for [[Ireland]]. Determined to return to the Isle of Man, he caused a storm and guided the ship towards the rocky coast of Contrary Head. His plan was interdicted through the intervention of St. Trinian. Invoked by the captain with a promise to build a chapel in his honour, the saint guided the ship safely into [[Peel, Isle of Man|Peel Harbour]]. Incensed, the buggane screamed, "St. Trinian should never have a whole church in Ellan Vannin."<ref name=Callow>[http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/celt/phy/phy18.htm Callow, Edward. "The Buggane's Vow", ''The Phynodderre and Other Legends of the Isle of Man'', J. Dean and Son, London, 1882]</ref> When the chapel came to be built, three times the local people put a roof on, and three times the buggane tore it off.
As magical creatures, bugganes were unable to cross water or stand on hallowed ground.<ref name=Morrison/>
The ''Buggan ny Hushtey'' lived in a large cave near the sea and was known for having no liking for lazy people.<ref>Morrison, Sophia. "Buggane ny Hushtey, the Buggane-of-the-Water: A Manx Folktale", ''Folklore'', Vol. 34, No. 4 (Dec. 31, 1923), pp. 349-351 {{jstor|1256555}}</ref> However, it should not be confused with the [[Cabyll-ushtey]], the Manx [[water horse]].
Bugganes were occasionally called upon by the [[fairy|fairies]] to punish people that had offended them. The buggane of [[Glen Maye]] would have pitched a lazy housewife into a waterfall for putting off baking until after sunset, had she not cut loose the strings of her apron to escape.<ref name=Morrison/> The buggane from Gob-na-Scuit was known for tearing the thatch off the haystacks, puffing the smoke down chimneys, and pushing sheep over the edge of the brooghs (a steep bank or grassy cliff).<ref>[http://www.feegan.com/fltales/fltales2.html "Old Nance and The Buggane", Feegan's, IOM]</ref>
===Finn MacColl and the Buggane=== In Manx legend, the Irish giant [[Fionn mac Cumhaill]] (Finn MacCool) crossed over to Mann and settled near Cregneash. The buggane from Barrule came to do battle, but Finn did not want to fight. Fionn's wife, Oonagh, disguised Fionn as a baby and tucked him in a cradle. When the buggane saw the size of the 'baby', he thought that its father, Fionn, must be a giant among giants, and so he left. They eventually met near [[Rushen|Kirk Christ Rushen]] and fought from sunrise to sunset. Fionn had one foot in the Big Sound, and so made the channel between the [[Calf of Man]] and [[Kitterland]], and the other foot was in the Little Sound, and so he made the narrow channel between Kitterland and the main island. The buggane was standing at Port Erin. He came off victorious and slashed Fionn awfully, so that he had to run to Ireland. Fionn could walk on the sea, but the buggane could not, so he tore out a tooth and threw it at Fionn. It hit him on the back of the head, and then it fell into the sea and became what is now called [[Chicken Rock]]. Fionn turned round and roared a mighty curse, "My seven swearings of a curse on it!" "Let it lie there for a vexation to the sons of men while water runs and grass grows!" And so it has.<ref name=Morrison/> The Irish version of the story has Finn's adversary a giant from [[Scotland]].
==In popular culture== * Bushys (Mount Murray Brewing) of [[Douglas, Isle of Man]] brews a light brown English bitter called "Bushy's Buggane".<ref>[http://www.ratebeer.com/beer/bushys-buggane/38855/ "Bushy's Buggane", Ratebeer.com]</ref> * Stories from the Isle of Man: The Buggane of St. Trinian's, featured in Season 6 (8 August 1969) of the BBC children's television series ''[[Jackanory]]''. * In ''[[The Last Apprentice]]'' series by [[Joseph Delaney]], a buggane features prominently in the seventh book, ''Rise of the Huntress''. * Buggane is featured in the fantasy novel ''[[The Road To Fero City]]'' by Morat, in which he is imprisoned for vandalising churches.

{{Infobox book | name = Caravan to Lhasa | title_orig = | image = Caravan to lhasa book cover.jpg | author = Kamal Ratna Tuladhar | publisher = Various | genre = [[Travel literature]] | release_date = 2011 (second edition) | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]]) | isbn = 9789994658916 }}
'''''Caravan to Lhasa''''' is a travel book and an account of the lives of expatriate [[People of Nepal|Nepalese]] merchants in [[Lhasa]] from the 1920s to the 1960s. Written by Kamal Ratna Tuladhar, the book describes the [[Caravan (travellers)|caravan]] journey from [[Kathmandu]] across the [[Himalaya]], and the life and times of the [[Newar]] traders in [[Tibet]] through the experiences of his merchant father [[Karuna Ratna Tuladhar]] (1920-2008) and uncles.<ref>{{cite news|last= Prasai |first= Ujjwal |title= Family History |url= http://www.ekantipur.com/the-kathmandu-post/2011/12/16/books/family-history/229395.html |accessdate=15 October 2012|newspaper=The Kathmandu Post |date=16 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Bajracharya |first= Himesh |title= Lhasa legacy |url= http://www.ekantipur.com/kantipur/news/news-detail.php?news_id=272818 |accessdate= 25 May 2013 |newspaper= Kantipur |date= 16 June 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Karuna Ratna spent 17 years in Lhasa, from 1935-1946 and 1949-1954. He was born in Kathmandu to a merchant family, and took over the ancestral shop in Lhasa after his father's death in 1935.
''Caravan to Lhasa'' is based on the centuries-old history of Kathmandu's [[Lhasa Newar (trans-Himalayan traders)|Lhasa Newar]] merchants who lived for long periods at their business houses in [[Tibet]] and India, and operated a trading network linking South and Central Asia.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/2013/06/2013623123438887107.html |title = Renewed Nepali trade route draws regional ire |last = Kaye|first = Melati |publisher = |date = 29 June 2013 |website = Al Jazeera |accessdate= 7 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://tibetanhistory-20thcentury.wikischolars.columbia.edu/Newar+Merchants+of+Kathmandu+in+Traditional+Tibet |title = Newar Merchants of Kathmandu in Traditional Tibet |last = Yoon |first = Sungoh |website = Tibetan Biographies |accessdate= 1 May 2014}}</ref>
The book ends with the final return of the merchants after the Chinese takeover of Tibet and the flight of the [[Dalai Lama]] to India in 1959. The first edition appeared in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|last=Aikat |first=Kajori |title=Book Review: Caravan to Lhasa |url= |accessdate= |newspaper=ECS |date=February 2005}} Page 99.</ref><ref>{{cite news|last= |first= |title=Just published |url=http://himalaya.socanth.cam.ac.uk/collections/journals/jns/pdf/JNS_05.pdf |accessdate= 29 March 2013 |newspaper=A Journal of Newar Studies |date=2004/05}} Page 11.</ref>
