{{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{good article}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[Sir]] | name = Ian McKellen | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=UK|size=100|CH|CBE}} | image = SDCC13 - Ian McKellen.jpg | caption = McKellen in 2013 | birth_name = Ian Murray McKellen | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1939|5|25}} {{cite news|title=Monitor|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=25 May 2012|issue=1208|page=21}} | birth_place = [[Burnley]], [[Lancashire]], England | residence = | occupation = Actor | years_active = 1959–present | partner = Brian Taylor (1964–1972)
[[Sean Mathias]] (1978–1988) | alma_mater = [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge]] | website = {{official website|http://www.mckellen.com/}} }} [[File:Jane Seymour and Ian McKellen in Amadeus, 1980 or 1981.jpg|thumb|right|McKellen (Antonio Salieri) alongside [[Jane Seymour (actress)|Jane Seymour]] (Constanze Mozart) in ''[[Amadeus]]'', c. 1981]] '''Sir Ian Murray McKellen''' {{post-nominals|country=UK|size=100%|CH|CBE}} (born 25 May 1939) is an English actor. He is the recipient of six [[Laurence Olivier Award]]s, a [[Tony Award]], a [[Golden Globe Award]], a [[Screen Actors Guild Award]], a [[British Independent Film Awards|BIF Award]], two [[Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actor|Saturn Awards]], four [[Drama Desk Award]]s, and two [[Critics' Choice Movie Award|Critics' Choice Awards]]. He has also received two [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] nominations, four [[BAFTA]] nominations and five [[Primetime Emmy Awards|Emmy Award]] nominations. McKellen's career spans genres ranging from [[William Shakespeare|Shakespearean]] and modern theatre to popular [[fantasy]] and science fiction. The BBC states that his "performances have guaranteed him a place in the canon of English stage and film actors".{{cite news|first=George|last=Jackson|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/nesbitt-does-the-honours-as-fellow-actor-mckellen-gets-ulster-degree-29047729.html|title=Nesbitt does the honours as fellow actor McKellen gets Ulster degree|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|date=4 February 2013|accessdate=4 February 2013|quote=McKellen is recognised as one of the greatest living actors.|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6pCURkX7p?url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/nesbitt-does-the-honours-as-fellow-actor-mckellen-gets-ulster-degree-29047729.html|archive-date=24 March 2017|dead-url=no}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-foyle-west-21314824|title=Sir Ian McKellen receives award from University of Ulster|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=3 February 2013|accessdate=3 February 2013|quote=[O]ne of the greatest actors on stage and screen [...] Sir Ian's performances have guaranteed him a place in the canon of English stage and film actors}} A recipient of every major theatrical award in the UK, McKellen is regarded as a [[British culture|British cultural icon]].{{cite news|title=British Actor Ian Mckellen in China for Shakespeare on Film|url=https://www.britishcouncil.cn/en/about/press/british-actor-ian-mckellen-china-shakespeare-film|agency=British Council|date=13 November 2016}}{{cite news|title=Thirty of the very best of British|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/10050832/Thirty-of-the-very-best-of-British.html|agency=The Telegraph|date=13 November 2016}} He started his professional career in 1961 at the [[Belgrade Theatre]] as a member of their highly regarded repertory company. In 1965, McKellen made his first [[West End theatre|West End]] appearance. In 1969, he was invited to join the [[Prospect Theatre Company]] to play the lead parts in Shakespeare's ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'' and [[Christopher Marlowe|Marlowe]]'s ''[[Edward II (play)|Edward II]]'', and he firmly established himself as one of the country's foremost classical actors. In the 1970s, McKellen became a stalwart of the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] and the [[National Theatre of Great Britain]]. He achieved worldwide fame for his film roles, including the [[Richard III of England|titular King]] in ''[[Richard III (1995 film)|Richard III]]'' (1995), [[James Whale]] in ''[[Gods and Monsters (film)|Gods and Monsters]]'' (1998), [[Magneto (comics)|Magneto]] in the [[X-Men (film series)|''X-Men'' films]], and [[Gandalf]] in ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|The Lord of the Rings]]'' and ''[[The Hobbit (film series)|The Hobbit]]'' trilogies. McKellen was appointed [[Order of the British Empire|Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in the [[1979 Birthday Honours]], was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the [[1991 New Year Honours]] for services to the performing arts, and made a [[Order of the Companions of Honour|Companion of Honour]] for services to drama and to equality in the [[2008 New Year Honours]].{{London Gazette|issue=47888|page=4 |supp=y|date=26 June 1979}}{{London Gazette|issue=52382|page=2 |supp=y|date=28 December 1990}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cinema.com/people/002/697/sir-ian-mckellen/index.phtml |title=Sir Ian McKellen |publisher=Cinema.com |date= |accessdate=18 July 2011}}{{London Gazette|issue=58557|page=4 |supp=y|date=29 December 2007}} He has been [[Coming out|openly gay]] since 1988, and continues to be a champion for [[LGBT social movements]] worldwide. He was awarded [[Freedom of the City|Freedom of the City of London]] in October 2014.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/ian-mckellen-receives-freedom-of-the-city-award-for-gay-rights-work-9830859.html |title=Ian McKellen receives Freedom of the City award for gay rights activism |work=The Independent |date=31 October 2014 |accessdate=26 August 2018}} ==Early life== McKellen was born on 25 May 1939 in [[Burnley]], Lancashire,{{sfn|Barratt|2006|p=1}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mckellen.com/life/per.htm|title=Sir Ian McKellen Personal Bio - Prior to launch of his website|first=Keith|last=Stern/CompuWeb|website=www.mckellen.com|accessdate=23 November 2018}} the son of Margery Lois (née Sutcliffe) and Denis Murray McKellen, a civil engineer. He was their second child, with a sister, Jean, five years his senior. Shortly before the outbreak of the Second World War in September 1939, his family moved to [[Wigan]]. They lived there until Ian was twelve years old, before relocating to [[Bolton]] in 1951, after his father had been promoted.{{cite journal|title=Pierless Youth|url=http://www.mckellen.com/writings/pierless.htm|accessdate=5 January 2014|magazine=The Sunday Times Magazine|date=2 January 1977}} The experience of living through the war as a young child had a lasting impact on him, and he later said that "only after peace resumed ... did I realise that war wasn't normal." When an interviewer remarked that he seemed quite calm in the aftermath of [[11 September attacks]], McKellen said: "Well, darling, you forget—I slept under a steel plate until I was four years old.".{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/nov/14/entertainment/et-ian-mckellen14 | title=Full Interview with McKellen | accessdate=8 January 2014 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Matea | last=Gold | date=14 November 2009}} McKellen's father was a civil engineer{{cite web|title=Sir Ian McKellen featured article|url=https://www.thegenealogist.co.uk/featuredarticles/2017/who-do-you-think-you-are/sir-ian-mckellen-420/|website=TheGenealogist|accessdate=24 January 2017}} and [[laity|lay]] preacher, and was of [[Protestant Irish]] and [[Scottish Reformation|Scottish]] descent.''Ian McKellen: an unofficial biography'', Mark Barratt, Virgin Books, 2005, p. 2 Both of McKellen's grandfathers were preachers, and his great-great-grandfather, James McKellen, was a "strict, evangelical [[Protestantism in Ireland|Protestant]] minister" in [[Ballymena|Ballymena, County Antrim]].{{cite web|title=Ian McKellen traces roots to Ballymena|url=http://www.u.tv/entertainment/Ian-McKellen-traces-roots-to-Ballymena/71222a03-8837-41ce-863b-a53974c8dddb|publisher=[[UTV (TV channel)|UTV]]|accessdate=3 February 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130204050036/http://www.u.tv/entertainment/Ian-McKellen-traces-roots-to-Ballymena/71222a03-8837-41ce-863b-a53974c8dddb|archivedate=4 February 2013|deadurl=yes}} His home environment was strongly Christian, but non-orthodox. "My upbringing was of low nonconformist Christians who felt that you led the Christian life in part by behaving in a Christian manner to everybody you met."{{cite news|last=Steele |first=Bruce C. |title=The Knight's Crusade |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1589/is_2001_Dec_25/ai_83451265 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080914105120/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1589/is_2001_Dec_25/ai_83451265 |work=The Advocate |date=11 December 2001 |archivedate=14 September 2008 |pages=36–38, 40–45 |accessdate=16 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} When he was 12, his mother died of breast cancer; his father died when he was 24. After his [[coming out]] as gay to his stepmother, Gladys McKellen, who was a member of the [[Quakers|Religious Society of Friends]], he said, "Not only was she not fazed, but as a member of a society which declared its indifference to people's sexuality years back, I think she was just glad for my sake that I wasn't lying anymore."{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/film-news/6694627/Sir-Ian-McKellen-Not-telling-parents-I-was-gay-remains-my-greatest-regret.html | title=McKellen about his stepmother | accessdate=8 January 2014 | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Stephen | last=Adams | date=30 November 2009}} His great-great-grandfather Robert J. Lowes was an activist and campaigner in the ultimately successful campaign for a [[Workweek and weekend|Saturday half-holiday]] in Manchester, the forerunner to the modern five-day work week, thus making Lowes a "grandfather of the modern weekend".{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/15/sir-ian-mckellensgreat-great-grandfather-helped-invent-weekend/|title=Sir Ian McKellen's great-great-grandfather helped invent the weekend|last=Furness|first=Hannah|date=15 January 2017|work=The Daily Telegraph|access-date=22 November 2017}} McKellen attended [[Bolton School]] (Boys' Division),{{cite web|title=Famous Old Boltonians |url=http://www.boltonschool.com/senior-boys/old-boys/famous-old-boltonians |publisher=Bolton School |accessdate=14 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119083833/http://www.boltonschool.com/senior-boys/old-boys/famous-old-boltonians |archivedate=19 January 2012 |df= }} of which he is still a supporter, attending regularly to talk to pupils. McKellen's acting career started at [[Bolton Little Theatre]], of which he is now the patron.{{cite web|url=http://www.blt.org.uk|title=Bolton Little Theatre|publisher=Bolton Little Theatre|accessdate=14 June 2009}} An early fascination with the theatre was encouraged by his parents, who took him on a family outing to ''[[Peter Pan]]'' at the [[Manchester Opera House|Opera House]] in Manchester when he was three.{{cite web|title=Ian McKellen From the Beginning|url=http://www.mckellen.com/life/per.htm|work=Ian McKellen Official Website|accessdate=5 January 2014}} When he was nine, his main Christmas present was a fold-away wood and bakelite Victorian theatre from [[Pollock's Toy Museum|Pollocks Toy Theatres]], with cardboard scenery and wires to push on the cut-outs of Cinderella and of [[Laurence Olivier]]'s Hamlet. His sister took him to his first Shakespeare play, ''[[Twelfth Night, or What You Will|Twelfth Night]]'',{{cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/theatre/pantos-grandest-dame-7280733.html|title=Panto's grandest Dame|last=Curtis|first=Nick|date=9 December 2005|work=[[Evening Standard]]|accessdate=7 February 2010|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213191654/http://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/theatre/pantos-grandest-dame-7280733.html|archive-date=13 December 2013|dead-url=no}} by the amateurs of Wigan's Little Theatre, shortly followed by their ''[[Macbeth]]'' and Wigan High School for Girls' production of ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'', with music by [[Felix Mendelssohn|Mendelssohn]], with the role of Bottom played by Jean McKellen, who continued to act, direct, and produce amateur theatre until her death.J. W. Braun, ''The Lord of the Films'' (ECW Press, 2009) In 1958, McKellen, at the age of 18, won a scholarship to [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge|St Catharine's College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]], where he read English literature.''[[Inside the Actors Studio]]''. Bravo. 8 December 2002. No. 5, season 9 He has since been made an [[List of Honorary Fellows of St Catharine's College, Cambridge|Honorary Fellow]] of the College. While at Cambridge, McKellen was a member of the [[Marlowe Society]], where he appeared in 23 plays over the course of 3 years. At that young age he was already giving performances that have since become legendary such as his Justice Shallow in ''[[Henry IV, Part 2|Henry IV]]'' alongside [[Trevor Nunn]] and [[Derek Jacobi]] (March 1959), ''[[Cymbeline]]'' (as Posthumus, opposite [[Margaret Drabble]] as Imogen) and ''[[The Tragical History of Doctor Faustus|Doctor Faustus]]''.{{cite book|title=Stratfordians|last=Trowbridge|first=Simon|year=2008|publisher=Editions Albert Creed|location=Oxford, England|isbn=978-0-9559830-1-6|pages=338–343}}{{cite web|url=http://www.societies.cam.ac.uk/marlowe/chronology.html |title=Marlowe Chronology |publisher=Cambridge University Marlowe Dramatic Society |accessdate=31 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615072500/http://www.societies.cam.ac.uk/marlowe/chronology.html |archivedate=15 June 2011 |df= }}{{cite book|last=Drabble|first=Margaret|authorlink=Margaret Drabble|editor=Novy, Marianne|title=Cross-cultural performances: differences in women's re-visions of Shakespeare|year=1993|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=Urbana|isbn=0-252-06323-6|page=130|chapter=Stratford revisited}} During this period McKellen had already been directed by [[Peter Hall (director)|Peter Hall]], [[John Barton (director)|John Barton]] and [[Dadie Rylands]], all of whom would have a huge impact on McKellen's future career. ==Career== ===Theatre=== [[File:9.24.13WaitingForGodot-NoMansLandPressJunketByLuigiNovi8.jpg|thumb|McKellen with actors [[Billy Crudup]] and [[Patrick Stewart]] on 24 September 2013 for a press junket at [[Sardi's]] restaurant for ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' and ''[[No Man's Land (play)|No Man's Land]]'']] McKellen made his first professional appearance in 1961 at the [[Belgrade Theatre]], as Roper in ''[[A Man for All Seasons]]'', although an audio recording of the Marlowe Society's ''Cymbeline'' had gone on commercial sale as part of the [[Argo Records (UK)|Argo]] Shakespeare series. After four years in regional [[repertory|repertory theatres]] he made his first [[West End theatre|West End]] appearance, in ''A Scent of Flowers'', regarded as a "notable success". In 1965 he was a member of [[Laurence Olivier]]'s National Theatre Company at the [[Old Vic]], which led to roles at the [[Chichester Festival Theatre|Chichester Festival]]. With the [[Prospect Theatre Company]], McKellen made his breakthrough performances of Richard II (directed by [[Richard Cottrell]]) and Marlowe's Edward II (directed by [[Toby Robertson]]) at the Edinburgh festival in 1969, the latter causing a storm of protest over the enactment of the homosexual Edward's lurid death.{{cite web | url= http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/obituary-toby-robertson-obe-theatre-director-1-2400165| publisher=''[[The Scotsman]]'' | accessdate=16 September 2013 | date=6 September 2012 | title= Obituary: Toby Robertson, OBE, theatre director | first=Alasdair | last= Steven | work=The Scotsman }} In the 1970s and 1980s McKellen became a well-known figure in British theatre, performing frequently at the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] and the [[Royal National Theatre]], where he played several leading Shakespearean roles, including the title role in ''[[Macbeth]]'' (which he had first played for [[Trevor Nunn]] in a "gripping...out of the ordinary" production, with [[Judi Dench]], at Stratford in 1976), and [[Iago]] in ''[[Othello]]'', in award-winning productions directed by Nunn. Both of these productions were adapted into television films, also directed by Nunn. In 2007 he returned to the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]], in productions of ''[[King Lear]]'' and ''[[The Seagull]]'', both directed by Trevor Nunn. In 2009 he appeared in a very popular revival of ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' at London's [[Haymarket Theatre]], directed by [[Sean Mathias]], and playing opposite [[Patrick Stewart]].{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821225446926|title=McKellen & Stewart Wait in Haymarket Godot|last=Paddock|first=Terri|date=31 October 2008|publisher=Whatsonstage.com|accessdate=8 July 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616065547/http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821225446926|archivedate=16 June 2011|deadurl=yes}}{{cite news|url=http://theater2.nytimes.com/2009/05/08/arts/08iht-LON8.html|title=McKellen and Stewart Deliver a 'Godot' With a Difference|last=Wolf|first=Matt|date=7 May 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate =8 July 2009}} He is Patron of [[English Touring Theatre]] and also President and Patron of the [[Little Theatre Guild of Great Britain]], an association of amateur theatre organisations throughout the UK.{{cite web|url=http://littletheatreguild.org/our-patron-sir-ian-mckellen-ch/|title=The Little Theatre Guild of Great Britain|publisher=Littletheatreguild.org|accessdate=15 December 2016}} In late August 2012, he took part in the [[2012 Summer Paralympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] of the [[2012 Summer Paralympics|London Paralympics]], portraying [[Prospero]] from ''[[The Tempest]]''.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19411225|title=BBC News – Paralympics: Games opening promises 'journey of discovery'|work=BBC News | date=29 August 2012}} In October 2017, McKellen played King Lear at Chichester Festival Theatre, a role which he said was likely to be his "last big Shakespearean part".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-41531398|title=Sir Ian McKellen says King Lear is his 'last big Shakespeare part'|work=BBC News | date=7 October 2017}} He will perform the play at the [[Duke of York's Theatre]] in London's West End during the summer of 2018.{{cite news|url=https://www.londontheatre.co.uk/theatre-news/news/ian-mckellen-to-play-king-lear-in-londons-west-end-this-summer|title=Ian McKellen to play King Lear in London's West End this summer|work=LondonTheatre.co.uk | date=8 February 2018}}{{cite web | url= https://www.londonboxoffice.co.uk/news/post/king-lear-ian-mackellen| accessdate=9 February 2018 | date=9 February 2018 | title= Don't miss Sir Ian McKellen as King Lear | first=Phil | last=Willmott | work=LondonBoxOffice.co.uk }} ===Popular success=== McKellen had taken film roles throughout his career—beginning in 1969 with his role of George Matthews in ''A Touch of Love'', and his first leading role was in 1980 as [[D. H. Lawrence]] in ''[[Priest of Love]]'',Cosmopolitan – "Ian McKellen bursts into film" – May 1981 but it was not until the 1990s that he became more widely recognised in this medium after several roles in blockbuster Hollywood films. In 1993 he had a supporting role as a South African tycoon in the critically acclaimed{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/six_degrees_of_separation|title=Six Degrees of Separation (1993)|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=15 June 2009}} ''[[Six Degrees of Separation (film)|Six Degrees of Separation]]'', in which he starred with [[Stockard Channing]], [[Donald Sutherland]], and [[Will Smith]]. In the same year, he appeared in minor roles in the television [[miniseries]] ''[[Tales of the City (1993 miniseries)|Tales of the City]]'', based on the novel by his friend [[Armistead Maupin]], and the film ''[[Last Action Hero]]'', in which he briefly played [[Death (personification)|Death]] opposite [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] and [[Charles Dance]]. Later in 1993, McKellen appeared in the television film ''[[And the Band Played On (film)|And the Band Played On]]'' about the discovery of the AIDS virus for which McKellen won a [[CableACE Awards|CableACE Award for Supporting Actor in a Movie or Miniseries]] and was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor – Miniseries or a Movie|Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Miniseries or a Movie]].{{cite web |title = Ian McKellen |author = |website = [[Emmy Award]] |date = n.d. |accessdate = 24 March 2017 |url = http://www.emmys.com/bios/ian-mckellen |ref = harv }} In 1995, he played the title role in ''[[Richard III (1995 film)|Richard III]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1068177-richard_iii|title=Richard III (1995)|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=15 June 2009}} which transported the setting into an alternative 1930s in which England is ruled by fascists. The film was a critical success.{{cite web|title=Notes |url=http://www.mckellen.com/cinema/richard/notes.htm |publisher=Ian McKellen Official Website |accessdate=15 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430075105/http://www.mckellen.com/cinema/richard/notes.htm |archivedate=30 April 2009 }} McKellen co-produced and co-wrote the film, adapting the play for the screen based on a stage production of Shakespeare's play directed by [[Richard Eyre]] for the [[Royal National Theatre]] in which McKellen had appeared. As executive producer he returned his £50,000 fee to complete the filming of the final battle.''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'', May 2006 In his review of the film, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' film critic Hal Hinson called McKellen's performance a "lethally flamboyant incarnation" and said his "florid mastery ... dominates everything".{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/richardiii.htm#hinson|title=A Rich 'Richard III' Rules|work=The Washington Post|date=19 January 1996}} His performance in the title role garnered [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role|BAFTA]] and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Golden Globe]] nominations for Best Actor and won the [[European Film Awards|European Film Award for Best Actor]]. His screenplay was nominated for the [[BAFTA Award for Best Adapted Screenplay]]. [[File:Ian McKellen.jpg|thumb|right|McKellen at the premiere of ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King|The Return of the King]]'' in [[Wellington]], New Zealand, 1 December 2003]] He appeared in the modestly acclaimed film{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/apt_pupil|title=Apt Pupil (1998)|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=15 June 2009}} ''[[Apt Pupil (film)|Apt Pupil]]'', which was directed by [[Bryan Singer]] and based on a story by [[Stephen King]]. McKellen portrayed a fugitive [[Nazi]] officer living under a [[pseudonym|false name]] in the US who is befriended by a curious teenager ([[Brad Renfro]]) who threatens to expose him unless he tells his story in detail. He was subsequently nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] for his role in the 1998 film ''[[Gods and Monsters (film)|Gods and Monsters]]'', wherein he played [[James Whale]], the director of ''[[Show Boat]]'' (1936) and ''[[Frankenstein (1931 film)|Frankenstein]]''. In 1999 McKellen was cast, again under the direction of Bryan Singer, to play the comic book supervillain [[Magneto (comics)|Magneto]] in the 2000 film ''[[X-Men (film)|X-Men]]'' and its sequels ''[[X2 (film)|X2: X-Men United]]'' (2003) and ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]'' (2006). He later made a short appearance as an older Magneto in 2014's ''[[X-Men: Days of Future Past]]'', sharing the role with [[Michael Fassbender]], who played a younger version of the character in 2011's ''[[X-Men: First Class]]''.{{cite web|url=http://screenrant.com/x-men-days-of-future-past-cast-patrick-stewart-ian-mckellen|title=Patrick Stewart & Ian McKellen Join 'X-Men: Days of Future Past'|date=27 November 2012|last=Keyes|first=Rob|publisher=Screenrant|accessdate=28 November 2012}} While filming the first ''X-Men'' film in 1999, McKellen was cast as the [[Wizard (Middle-earth)|wizard]] [[Gandalf]] in [[Peter Jackson]]'s three-film adaptation of [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''The Lord of the Rings'']] (consisting of ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring|The Fellowship of the Ring]]'' (2001), ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers|The Two Towers]]'' (2002), and ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King|The Return of the King]]'' (2003) ). He received honors from the [[Screen Actors Guild]] for Best Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture for his work in ''The Fellowship of the Ring'' and was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]] for the same role. He provided the voice of Gandalf for several video game adaptations of the ''Lord of the Rings'' films,{{cite web|title=2000's|publisher=Ian McKellen Official Website|url=http://www.mckellen.com/cinema/index0.htm|accessdate =25 April 2008}} then reprised the role on screen in Jackson's film adaptation of ''[[The Hobbit (film series)|The Hobbit]]'', which was released in three parts from 2012 to 2014.{{cite web|last=Rottenberg|first=Josh|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/01/10/the-hobbit-scoop-ian-mckellan-and-andy-serkis-on-board|title=Hobbit' scoop: Ian McKellen and Andy Serkis on board|publisher=Insidemovies.ew.com|date=10 January 2011|accessdate=18 July 2011}} On 16 March 2002, he hosted ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. In 2003, McKellen made a guest appearance as himself on the American cartoon show ''[[The Simpsons]]'' in a special British-themed episode entitled "[[The Regina Monologues]]", along with the then UK Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] and author [[J. K. Rowling]]. In April and May 2005, he played the role of Mel Hutchwright in [[Granada Television]]'s long running British soap opera, ''[[Coronation Street]]'', fulfilling a lifelong ambition. He narrated [[Richard Bell (director)|Richard Bell]]'s film ''Eighteen'' as a grandfather who leaves his World War II memoirs on audio-cassette for his teenage grandson. McKellen has appeared in limited release films, such as ''[[Emile (film)|Emile]]'' (which was shot in three weeks following the ''X2'' shoot),{{cite web|url=http://www.mckellen.com/cinema/emile/words.htm|title=Adrian Salpeter interviews Ian McKellen about Emile|work=Ian McKellen Official Website|accessdate=27 June 2013}} ''[[Neverwas]]'' and ''[[Asylum (2005 film)|Asylum]]''. He appeared as Sir Leigh Teabing in ''[[The Da Vinci Code (film)|The Da Vinci Code]]''. During a 17 May 2006 interview on ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'' with the ''Da Vinci Code'' cast and director, [[Matt Lauer]] posed a question to the group about how they would have felt if the film had borne a prominent disclaimer that it is a work of fiction, as some religious groups wanted. McKellen responded, "I've often thought the Bible should have a disclaimer in the front saying 'This is fiction.' I mean, walking on water? It takes... an act of faith. And I have faith in this movie – not that it's true, not that it's factual, but that it's a jolly good story." He continued, "And I think audiences are clever enough and bright enough to separate out fact and fiction, and discuss the thing when they've seen it".{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/blog/2006/05/17/ian-mckellen-unable-to-suspend-disbelief-while-reading-the-bible/ |title="Ian McKellen Unable to Suspend Disbelief While Reading the Bible." |accessdate=20 May 2006 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614150617/http://www.usmagazine.com/blog/2006/05/17/ian-mckellen-unable-to-suspend-disbelief-while-reading-the-bible/ |archivedate=14 June 2006 }} ''Us Weekly''. 17 May 2006. McKellen appeared in the 2006 BBC series of [[Ricky Gervais]]' comedy series ''[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]]'', where he played himself directing Gervais' character [[Andy Millman]] in a play about gay lovers. McKellen received a 2007 [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor - Comedy Series]] nomination for his performance. In 2009 he portrayed Number Two in ''[[The Prisoner (2009 miniseries)|The Prisoner]]'', a remake of the 1967 cult series ''[[The Prisoner]]''.{{cite news|title=The Prisoner: remake of a 1960s TV classic|last=Wilson|first=Benji|date=11 April 2010|newspaper=The Sunday Times|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article7091471.ece|location=London}} In 2013, McKellen co-starred in the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] sitcom ''[[Vicious (TV series)|Vicious]]'' as Freddie Thornhill, alongside [[Derek Jacobi]]. The series revolves around an elderly gay couple who have been together for 50 years. On 23 August 2013 the show was renewed for a six-episode second series which began airing in June 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/presscentre/ep1week23/vicious|title=Vicious|website=ITV Press Centre|publisher=ITV|accessdate=4 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a509391/vicious-renewed-for-second-series-by-itv-job-lot-moving-to-itv2.html|title='Vicious' renewed for second series by ITV, 'Job Lot' moving to ITV2|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=23 August 2013|accessdate=7 September 2013}} In November 2013, McKellen appeared in the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' 50th anniversary comedy homage ''[[The Five(ish) Doctors Reboot]]''."[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03lv3mj The Five(ish) Doctors Reboot]", BBC programmes, retrieved 26 November 2013 In October 2015, McKellen appeared as Norman to [[Anthony Hopkins]]' Sir in a [[BBC Two]] production of [[Ronald Harwood]]'s ''[[The Dresser (2015 film)|The Dresser]]'', alongside [[Edward Fox (actor)|Edward Fox]] and [[Emily Watson]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-34660715 |title=Ian McKellen: 'Working with Anthony Hopkins was bliss' – BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=31 October 2015 |accessdate=31 October 2015}} In 2017, McKellen voiced [[List of Disney's Beauty and the Beast characters#Cogsworth|Cogsworth]], the [[Beast (Disney)|Beast]]'s loyal [[majordomo]], who was turned into a pendulum clock, in a [[Beauty and the Beast (2017 film)|live-action adaptation]] of Disney's ''[[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|Beauty and the Beast]]''.{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Ian McKellen to Play Cogsworth in Disney's 'Beauty and the Beast' (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/beauty-beast-ian-mckellen-cogsworth-1201464763/|accessdate=11 April 2015|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=10 April 2015}} ==Personal life== McKellen and his first partner, Brian Taylor, a history teacher from [[Bolton]], began their relationship in 1964.{{cite news|url=http://www.tiscali.co.uk/entertainment/film/biographies/ian_mckellen_biog.html |title=Ian McKellen profile at Tiscali |work=Tiscali Film and TV |accessdate=11 April 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050217093636/http://www.tiscali.co.uk/entertainment/film/biographies/ian_mckellen_biog.html |archivedate=17 February 2005 |df= }} Their relationship lasted for eight years, ending in 1972. They lived in London, where McKellen continued to pursue his career as an actor. For over a decade, he has lived in a five-storey Victorian conversion in [[Narrow Street]], [[Limehouse]].{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article559425.ece|title=Sir Ian McKellen|work=[[The Times]]|date=27 August 2005|accessdate=10 September 2005|location=London}} In 1978 he met his second partner, [[Sean Mathias]], at the [[Edinburgh Festival]]. This relationship lasted until 1988, and according to Mathias, was tempestuous, with conflicts over McKellen's success in acting versus Mathias's somewhat less-successful career. Mathias later directed McKellen in ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' at the [[Theatre Royal Haymarket]] in 2009. The pair entered into a business partnership with [[Evgeny Lebedev]], purchasing the lease of [[The Grapes, Limehouse|The Grapes]] public house in Narrow Street."[http://thegrapes.co.uk/history.php The Grapes History]", thegrapes.co.uk. McKellen is an [[atheist]].{{cite web|title=Famous atheists and their beliefs|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/25/living/gallery/atheists/|website=cnn.com|accessdate=12 November 2015}} In the late 1980s, McKellen lost his appetite for meat except for fish, and has since followed a mainly [[pescetarian]] diet.[http://www.mckellen.com/epost/m000905.htm ''Correspondence with Ian McKellen—Vegetarianism''] from ''Ian McKellen Official Website''. Retrieved 4 February 2008. In 2001, Ian McKellen received the Artist Citizen of the World Award (France).[https://institutcitoyenducinema.wordpress.com/artiste-citoyen-du-monde/ "Artist winners Prize Citizen of the World"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418093331/https://institutcitoyenducinema.wordpress.com/artiste-citoyen-du-monde/ |date=18 April 2015 }}. Institut Citoyen du Cinéma He has a tattoo of the Elvish number nine, written using [[J. R. R Tolkien]]'s [[Constructed script]] of [[Tengwar]], on his shoulder in reference to his involvement in the ''Lord of the Rings'' and the fact that his character was one of the original nine companions of the [[Fellowship of the Ring (characters)|Fellowship of the Ring]]. The other actors of "The Fellowship" ([[Elijah Wood]], [[Sean Astin]], [[Orlando Bloom]], [[Billy Boyd (actor)|Billy Boyd]], [[Sean Bean]], [[Dominic Monaghan]] and [[Viggo Mortensen]]) have the same tattoo. [[John Rhys-Davies]], whose character was also one of the original nine companions, arranged for his stunt double to get the tattoo instead.{{cite web| url =http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue348/interview.html |title = The stars of The Lord of the Rings trilogy reach their journey's end| publisher =SciFi.com| accessdate =31 May 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070306100400/http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue348/interview.html |archivedate = 6 March 2007|deadurl=yes}} He was diagnosed with [[prostate cancer]] in 2006.{{cite news|first=Sherna |last=Noah |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/sir-ian-mckellen-speaks-of-prostate-cancer-shock-8405396.html |title=Sir Ian McKellen speaks of prostate cancer shock |work=The Independent |date=11 December 2012 |accessdate=5 August 2013 |location=London}} In 2012, McKellen stated on his blog that "There is no cause for alarm. I am examined regularly and the cancer is contained. I've not needed any treatment."{{cite news |last=Gwynedd |first=Myrddin |date=14 December 2012 |title=Ian McKellen clarifies prostate cancer reports |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=10853970 |newspaper=The New Zealand Herald |location= |publisher=APN New Zealand |accessdate=2 September 2014}} He became an ordained minister of the [[Universal Life Church]] in early 2013{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2013/03/19/sir-ian-mckellen-to-marry-sir-patrick-stewart-no-not-like-that/|title=Patrick Stewart's Wedding and Ian McKellen - TIME.com|work=TIME.com | date=19 March 2013}} in order to preside over the marriage of his friend and ''X-Men'' co-star [[Patrick Stewart]] to the singer [[Sunny Ozell]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2013/09/09/patrick-stewart-sunny-ozell-wedding-ian-mckellen/2785053/|title=Patrick Stewart weds girlfriend; Ian McKellen officiates|last=Blum|first=Haley|date=9 September 2013|work=USA Today|access-date=22 November 2017}} McKellen was awarded an honorary Doctorate of Letters by [[Cambridge University]] on 18 June 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.alumni.cam.ac.uk/news/honorary-degrees-2014|title=Honorary degrees 2014|website=Cambridge University Alumni News|accessdate=19 June 2014}} He was made a [[Freedom of the City|Freeman of the city of London]] on Thursday 30 October 2014. The ceremony took place at [[Guildhall, London|Guildhall]] in London. McKellen was nominated by London's Lord Mayor Fiona Woolf, who said he was chosen as he was an "exceptional actor" and "tireless campaigner for equality".{{cite web|url=https://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/about-the-city/what-we-do/media-centre/news-releases/2014/Pages/sir-ian-mckellen-receives-freedom-of-the-city-of-london.aspx|title=Sir Ian McKellen receives Freedom of the City of London|work=cityoflondon.gov.uk|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030191346/https://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/about-the-city/what-we-do/media-centre/news-releases/2014/Pages/sir-ian-mckellen-receives-freedom-of-the-city-of-london.aspx|archivedate=30 October 2014|deadurl=yes}} He is also a Fellow of [[St Catherine's College, Oxford]].{{cite web|url=http://www.stcatz.ox.ac.uk/Academic-Staff/Emeritus-Fellows|title=Emeritus Fellows - www.stcatz.ox.ac.uk|website=www.stcatz.ox.ac.uk|accessdate=23 November 2018}} ==LGBT activism== ===LGBT rights campaigning=== [[File:McKellen 2010.jpg|thumb|McKellen at [[Manchester Pride]] 2010]] While McKellen had made his [[sexual orientation]] known to fellow actors early on in his stage career, it was not until 1988 that he [[coming out|came out]] to the general public, in a programme on [[BBC Radio]].An archived recording of the programme is online: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/archive/gay_rights/12012.shtml "''Third Ear'': Section 28"], BBC Radio 3, 27 January 1988 The context that prompted McKellen's decision – overriding any concerns about a possible negative effect on his career – was that the controversial Section 28 of the Local Government Bill, known simply as [[Section 28]], was then under consideration in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|British Parliament]]. Section 28 proposed prohibiting local authorities from promoting homosexuality "... as a kind of pretended family relationship".{{cite news|date=20 January 2000|publisher=BBC|title=When gay became a four-letter word|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/611704.stm|accessdate=5 January 2010}} McKellen became active in fighting the proposed law, and, during a [[BBC Radio 3]] programme where he debated Section 28 with the conservative journalist [[Peregrine Worsthorne]], declared himself gay.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/archive/gay_rights/12012.shtml "''Third Ear'': Section 28"], BBC Radio 3, 27 January 1988 McKellen has stated that he was influenced in his decision by the advice and support of his friends, among them noted gay author [[Armistead Maupin]]. In a 1998 interview that discusses the 29th anniversary of the [[Stonewall riots]], McKellen commented,
I have many regrets about not having come out earlier, but one of them might be that I didn't engage myself in the politicking.Mendelsohn, Scott, [http://bombsite.com/issues/65/articles/2189 "Ian McKellen"], ''[[BOMB Magazine]]''. Fall 1998. Retrieved on [18 July 2012.]
He has said of this period:
My own participating in that campaign was a focus for people [to] take comfort that if Ian McKellen was on board for this, perhaps it would be all right for other people to be as well, gay and straight.
Section 28 was, however, enacted and remained on the statute books until 2000 in Scotland and 2003 in England and Wales. Section 28 never applied in Northern Ireland. In 2003, during an appearance on ''[[Have I Got News For You]]'', McKellen claimed when he visited [[Michael Howard]], then [[Secretary of State for the Environment|Environment Secretary]] (responsible for local government), in 1988 to lobby against Section 28, Howard refused to change his position but did ask him to leave an autograph for his children. McKellen agreed, but wrote, "Fuck off, I'm gay."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/3266571.stm 10 things we didn't know this time last week]. BBC News. 14 November 2003. McKellen described Howard's junior ministers, Conservatives [[David Wilshire]] and Dame [[Jill Knight, Baroness Knight of Collingtree|Jill Knight]], who were the architects of Section 28, as the 'ugly sisters' of a political pantomime.{{cite web|url=http://www.mckellen.com/writings/activism/8807section28.htm|title='Section 28'|publisher=Ian McKellen Official Website|date=1 July 1988|accessdate=20 August 2015}} [[File:Ian McKellen at Europride 2003 Parade.jpg|thumb|McKellen at [[Europride]] 2003 in [[Manchester]]]] McKellen has continued to be very active in [[LGBT rights]] efforts. In a statement on his website regarding his activism, the actor commented that: {{quote|I have been reluctant to lobby on other issues I most care about – [[nuclear weapon]]s (against), religion ([[atheist]]), capital punishment (anti), AIDS (fund-raiser) because I never want to be forever spouting, diluting the impact of addressing my most urgent concern; legal and social equality for gay people worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.mckellen.com/activism/index.htm|title=Activism|publisher=Ian McKellen Official Website|accessdate=13 July 2008}}}} McKellen is a co-founder of [[Stonewall (UK)|Stonewall]], an LGBT rights [[Lobbying|lobby]] group in the United Kingdom, named after the [[Stonewall riots]]. McKellen is also patron of [[LGBT History Month]], [[Pride London]], Oxford Pride, GAY-GLOS, [[The Lesbian & Gay Foundation]],{{cite web|url=http://www.lgf.org.uk/sir-ian-mckellen|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719022428/http://www.lgf.org.uk/sir-ian-mckellen|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 July 2011|title=Aim High|publisher=the Lesbian & Gay Foundation|accessdate=15 June 2009}} and [[FFLAG]] where he appears in their video "Parents Talking".{{cite web|url=http://www.fflag.org.uk|title=Home|author=Toby|work=fflag.org.uk}} In 1994, at the closing ceremony of the [[Gay Games]], he briefly took the stage to address the crowd, saying, "I'm Sir Ian McKellen, but you can call me Serena": This nickname, given to him by [[Stephen Fry]], had been circulating within the gay community since McKellen's knighthood was conferred. In 2002, he was the Celebrity Grand Marshal of the San Francisco Pride Parade{{Cite web|url=http://www.mckellen.com/events/sfpride.htm|title=SF Pride 2002 {{!}} San Francisco {{!}} Ian McKellen|date=n.d.|website=www.mckellen.com|access-date=2 February 2018}} and he attended the Academy Awards with his then-boyfriend, New Zealander Nick Cuthell. In 2006, McKellen spoke at the pre-launch of the 2007 LGBT History Month in the UK, lending his support to the organisation and its founder, [[Sue Sanders]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lgbthistorymonth.org.uk/prelaunch.htm|title=LGBT History Month 2007 PreLaunch|publisher=LGBT History Month|date=20 November 2006}} In 2007, he became a patron of [[The Albert Kennedy Trust]], an organisation that provides support to young, homeless and troubled LGBT people.{{cite web|url=http://www.akt.org.uk/latest-news.htm|title=Ian McKellen becomes the Albert Kennedy Trust's new patron|publisher=The Albert Kennedy Trust|date=5 January 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070211033940/http://www.akt.org.uk/latest-news.htm|archivedate=11 February 2007|deadurl=yes}} In 2006, he became a patron of Oxford Pride, stating:
I send my love to all members of Oxford Pride, their sponsors and supporters, of which I am proud to be one... Onlookers can be impressed by our confidence and determination to be ourselves and gay people, of whatever age, can be comforted by the occasion to take the first steps towards coming out and leaving the closet forever behind.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/oxfordshire/4754409.stm |title=Sir Ian becomes gay pride patron |publisher=BBC News |date=10 May 2006 |accessdate=5 January 2014}}
McKellen has taken his activism internationally, and caused a major stir in Singapore, where he was invited to do an interview on a morning show and shocked the interviewer by asking if they could recommend him a [[gay bar]]; the programme immediately ended.{{cite news|last1=Hudson|first1=Chrys|title=Ian McKellen's gay comment causes a stir on Singaporean TV|url=http://www.gmax.co.za/feel07/10/22-ianmc.html|accessdate=12 April 2017|work=GMax.co.za|date=22 October 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523050230/http://www.gmax.co.za/feel07/10/22-ianmc.html|archivedate=23 May 2012|deadurl=y}} In December 2008, he was named in ''[[Out (magazine)|Out'']]{{'s}} annual Out 100 list.[http://out.com/out100/nominees_8.asp "Ian McKellen."] ''[[Out (magazine)|Out]]''. December 2008. Retrieved 28 April 2009. In 2010, McKellen extended his support for [[Liverpool]]'s [[Homotopia Liverpool (festival)|Homotopia festival]] in which a group of gay and lesbian [[Merseyside]] teenagers helped to produce an anti-homophobia campaign pack for schools and youth centres across the city.{{cite web|author=Staff Writer|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2010/03/10/ian-mckellen-backs-liverpool-anti-homophobia-effort|title=Ian McKellen backs Liverpool anti-homophobia effort|publisher=Pink News|accessdate=20 June 2012}} In May 2011, he called [[Sergey Sobyanin]], Moscow's mayor, a "coward" for refusing to allow gay parades in the city.{{cite web|author=Advocate.com Editors |url=http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2011/05/26/McKellan_Calls_Moscow_Mayor_a_Coward |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110528124620/http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2011/05/26/McKellan_Calls_Moscow_Mayor_a_Coward/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 May 2011 |title=McKellen Calls Moscow Mayor a Coward | News |publisher=The Advocate |accessdate=18 July 2011 }} In 2014, he was named in the top 10 on the World Pride Power list.{{cite web|title=World Pride Power List 2014 |url=http://www.worldpridepowerlist.com/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605192516/http://www.worldpridepowerlist.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 June 2012 |publisher=The Guardian }} ===Charity work=== In April 2010, along with actors [[Brian Cox (actor)|Brian Cox]] and [[Eleanor Bron]], McKellen appeared in a series of TV advertisements to support [[Age UK]], the charity recently formed from the merger of [[Age Concern]] and [[Help the Aged]]. All three actors gave their time free of charge.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/apr/19/age-uk|title=Hollywood actors star in Age UK ad|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=19 April 2010|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=21 April 2010|location=London}} A cricket fan since childhood, McKellen umpired in March 2011 for a charity cricket match in New Zealand to support earthquake victims of the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake|February 2011 Christchurch earthquake]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=10710623 |title=Cricket: 'Fill the Basin' teams named |publisher=The New Zealand Herald |date=7 March 2011 |accessdate=5 January 2014}}{{cite web|title=Hollywood vs Wellywood fills The Basin|url=http://www.newzealand.com/travel/media/press-releases/2011/march-2011/tourism-news_hollywood-vs-wellywood-fills-basin_press-release.cfm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203115058/http://www.newzealand.com/travel/media/press-releases/2011/march-2011/tourism-news_hollywood-vs-wellywood-fills-basin_press-release.cfm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=3 February 2014|work=New Zealand.com|publisher=Tourism New Zealand|accessdate=22 January 2014|date=14 March 2011}} McKellen is an honorary board member for the New York and Washington, DC based organization Only Make Believe.{{cite web |author=Panoptic Artifex – Christopher Baima & Greg Sweet |url=http://www.onlymakebelieve.org/who/honorary-board/ |title=Honorary Board |publisher=Only Make Believe |date=15 September 2013 |accessdate=5 January 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231035245/http://onlymakebelieve.org/who/honorary-board/ |archive-date=31 December 2013 |dead-url=yes }} Only Make Believe creates and performs interactive plays in children's hospitals and care facilities. He was honoured by the organisation in 2012{{cite journal|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20643724,00.html |title=Ian McKellen Makes Magic... Through Charity |publisher=Entertainment Weekly |date=2 November 2012 |accessdate=5 January 2014}} and hosted their annual Make Believe on Broadway Gala in November 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/06/ian-mckellen-undies-broadway_n_4225319.html |title=Ian McKellen Strips To His Undies at the Only Make Believe Gala |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 6 November 2013|accessdate=5 January 2014 |first=Liat |last=Kornowski}} He garnered publicity for the organisation by stripping down to his Lord of the Rings underwear on stage. McKellen also has a history of supporting individual theatres. While in New Zealand filming ''[[The Hobbit (film series)|The Hobbit]]'' in 2012, he announced a special New Zealand tour "Shakespeare, Tolkien, and You!", with proceeds going to help save the Isaac Theatre Royal, which suffered extensive damage during the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]]. McKellen said he opted to help save the building as it was the last theatre he played in New Zealand (''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' in 2010) and the locals' love for it made it a place worth supporting.{{cite web|author=RadioLIVE|url=http://www.radiolive.co.nz/Sir-Ian-McKellen-on-fundraising-for-the-Isaac-Theatre-Royal/tabid/506/articleID/27273/Default.aspx|title=Sir Ian McKellen on fundraising for the Isaac Theatre Royal|publisher=MediaWorks|accessdate=13 April 2012}} In July 2017, he performed a new one-man show for a week at [[Park Theatre (London)]], donating the proceeds to the theatre.{{Cite news| issn = 0307-1235| last = Cavendish| first = Dominic| title = Ian McKellen at Park Theatre review: the secret of his success is not lofty knightliness but spry mateyness| work = The Telegraph| accessdate = 24 July 2017| date = 3 July 2017| url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/theatre/what-to-see/ian-mckellen-park-theatre-review-secret-success-not-lofty-knightliness/}} ===Other work=== A friend of [[Ian Charleson]] and an admirer of his work, McKellen contributed an entire chapter to ''For Ian Charleson: A Tribute''.Ian McKellen, Alan Bates, Hugh Hudson, et al. [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0094702500 ''For Ian Charleson: A Tribute'']. London: Constable and Company, 1990. pp. 125–130. A recording of McKellen's voice is heard before performances at the [[Royal Festival Hall]], reminding patrons to ensure their mobile phones and watch alarms are switched off and to keep coughing to a minimum.{{cite news | title = How to deal with the very worst concert nuisances | last = White | first = Michael | date = 20 June 2011 | newspaper = The Daily Telegraph | url = http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/culture/michaelwhite/100054207/how-to-deal-with-the-very-worst-concert-nuisances/ |accessdate=24 June 2011 | location=London}}{{cite web|url = http://www.musicweb-international.com/SandH/2010/Jul-Dec10/traviata0807.htm | title = Verdi, La traviata: Soloists, chorus and orchestra of the Royal Opera House. Conductor: Yves Abel. [[File:Issa Kostoyev.jpg|thumb|Issa Kostoyev in 2008]]
'''Issa Magomatovich Kostoyev''' ({{lang-ru|Исса́ Магоме́тович Косто́ев}}; born August 8, 1942) is a [[Russia]]n government attorney and bureaucrat. He was the representative in the [[Federation Council (Russia)|Federation Council]] from the executive body of state power of the Republic of [[Ingushetia]] (2002–2009),<ref>[https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/1509225 Исса Костоев, в 1973—1992 годах — старший следователь по особо важным делам; в 1996—2002 годах — начальник международно-правового управления Генеральной прокуратуры России] // [[Kommersant]]</ref> and a member of the Federation Council Committee on Defense and Security and Commission on Natural Monopolies. State Counselor of Justice 2 classes.<ref>Decree President of the Russian Federation of June 20, 1996 No. 960</ref>
== Early life == He graduated from [[Al-Farabi Kazakh National University]] with a specialty in jurisprudence.<ref>[http://www.russia-today.ru/archive/2003/no_16/16_law.htm Почему чем опаснее преступление, тем неуязвимее преступник // Российская Федерация сегодня, 2003]</ref><ref>[https://camonitor.kz/31577-issa-kostoev-sledovatel-raskryvshiy-delo-chikatilo-vyros-v-kazahstane.html Исса Костоев. Следователь, раскрывший «дело Чикатило», вырос в Казахстане]</ref>
== Career == Kostoyev began working in the prosecutor's offices of North Ossetia, the Chechen-Ingush Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic, the prosecutor's office of the USSR and the Prosecutor General's Office of the Russian Federation. He headed investigative groups that engaged in the search for Rostov maniac [[Andrei Chikatilo]]<ref>[http://www.garweb.ru/conf/supcourt/20030410/smi/msg.asp@id_msg140654.htm Исса Костоев — человек, который поймал Чикатило]</ref><ref>[https://www.sovsekretno.ru/articles/id/5753 Он раскрыл дело Чикатило]</ref> and Smolensk maniac [[:ru:Стороженко, Владимир Викторович|Vladimir Storozhenko]]<ref>[http://www.allkriminal.ru/article/15991/640 Смоленский душитель Владимир Стороженкo]</ref>.
He supports the death penalty for serial killers and pedophiles.<ref>[http://ingush-empire.com/2011/10/исса-костоев-расстреливать-надо/ Исса Костоев: расстреливать надо]</ref>
==Awards and honours== * [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour]] (1982) * [[Medal "Veteran of Labour"|Medal Veteran of Labour]] (1989) * [[Honoured Lawyer of Russia]] (1997)<ref>Decree President of the Russian Federation of January 9, 1997 No. 4</ref> * [[Order of Honour (Russia)|Order of Honour]] (2002) * [[Order For Merit to the Fatherland]] 4th class (2007)<ref>[http://document.kremlin.ru/doc.asp?ID=43551&PSC=1&PT=3&Page=1Decree President of the Russian Federation No. 1762]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.aif.ru/society/law/ya_chuvstvoval_on_ubiyca_intervyu_so_sledovatelem_poymavshim_chikatilo «Я чувствовал — он убийца»: интервью со следователем, поймавшим Чикатило]

'''Jabez Huntington''' (7 August 1719 – 5 October 1786) was a merchant and politician from [[Connecticut Colony]].
Jabez Huntington graduated from [[Yale University|Yale]] in 1741, engaged in the [[West India]] trade, and amassed a fortune. After 1759 he was frequently a member of the legislature, speaker for several years, and also a member of the council. At the beginning of the [[American Revolutionary War]], he owned a large amount of shipping, and lost heavily by the capture of his vessels. He was among the most active on the committee of safety during the war; and in the September 1776 session of the Connecticut assembly he and [[David Wooster]] were appointed Major Generals. On the death of Wooster in 1777 Jabez was placed in charge of the entire Connecticut militia. His great exertions in the patriot cause and his heavy losses impaired his physical and mental powers, and he was thus compelled to resign his employments in 1779.<ref name=EBH>{{cite book|last=Huntington|first=Elijah B.|title=Genealogical Memoir of the Huntington Family|authorlink=Elijah Baldwin Huntington|year=1863|pages=107–108}}</ref>
==Family== Jabez was born on 7 Aug 1719 in [[Norwich, Connecticut]] to Joshua and Hannah (Perkins) Huntington.<ref>Huntington, p84</ref> He married first Elizabeth (20 Jan 1741 - 1 Jul 1745), the daughter of Samuel and Elizabeth (Tracy) Backus. They had two children, [[Jedediah Huntington|Jedediah]] in 1743, and Andrew who was born the month before his mother's death. He married his second wife, Hannah Williams (23 Jul 1726 - 25 Mar 1807) of [[Pomfret, Connecticut]], on 10 Jul 1746. They had six children: Joshua, Hannah (died at age eight), Ebenezer, Elizabeth, Mary, and Zachariah.<ref name="Huntington, pages=161-168">Huntington, pages=161-168</ref> Jabez died on 5 Oct 1786 at Norwich.<ref>Huntington, p108</ref>
Jabez's son [[Jedidiah Huntington]] also served in the American Revolution, and after it was over was collector of customs at [[New London, Connecticut]], for many years.
Jabez's son, Andrew Huntington (born 21 June 1745; died 7 April 1824) engaged in commercial pursuits, and in 1795 was a manufacturer of paper at the falls of Norwich. He was judge of probate in his district in 1813. During the American Revolution he was a commissary of brigade.
Jabez's son Joshua Huntington (born in Norwich, 16 August 1751) began business with his father. After the [[Battle of Lexington]], he commanded a company of 100 men of the town, and joined [[Israel Putnam|Putnam]]'s brigade. Subsequently, he was ordered by the [[Continental Congress]] to build a frigate of 36 guns, which was constructed in the [[Thames River (Connecticut)|Thames]] at Gale's Ferry in 1777.
Jabez's son [[Ebenezer Huntington]] served in the American Revolution and then became a member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[Connecticut]].<ref name="Huntington, pages=161-168"/>
==Notes== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox person | name = Justin Meyer | image =Justin Meyer1.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Raymond Meyer | birth_date = 11 November 1938 | birth_place = [[Bakersfield, California]], USA | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|2002|08|06|1938|11|11}} | death_place = [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]], USA | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = Vintner and enologist | known_for = Co-founding [[Silver Oak Cellars]]
His vast expertise in winemaking and being a major influence in the [[American Vineyard Foundation]], which he presided in the 1990s. }} '''Justin Meyer''' (born '''Raymond Meyer''', 11 November 1938{{spaced ndash}}6 August 2002) was an American vintner, enologist, and monk of the [[Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools|Christian Brothers]]. He was the founder along with [[Ray Duncan]] of [[Silver Oak Cellars]] in 1972, a successful winery based in the [[Napa Valley]] and [[Alexander Valley]]. Today Duncan's sons [[David Duncan (vintner)|David Duncan]] and Tim Duncan run Silver Oak Cellars, as well as [[Twomey Cellars]], established in 1999. Meyer sold his share of the company to Duncan in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.cobizmag.com/articles/colorado-business-hall-of-fame-ray-duncan|title=Colorado Business Hall of Fame: Ray Duncan|publisher=''[[ColoradoBiz]]''|date=1 January 2012|accessdate=19 March 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cobizmag.com/articles/the-cult-of-cabernet|title=The cult of cabernet|publisher=''[[ColoradoBiz]]'', accessed via [[HighBeam Research]]|date=22 May 2009|accessdate=19 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120110231430/http://www.cobizmag.com/articles/the-cult-of-cabernet/|archivedate=10 January 2012|df=}} One of California's top wine experts, he was President of the [[American Vineyard Foundation]] in the 1990s and also held numerous other positions in the wine industry. The ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' cites Meyer as "one of the legends of the Napa Valley".{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/wine/article/SON-OF-SILVER-OAK-The-scion-of-one-of-Napa-s-2566425.php|title=SON OF SILVER OAK / The scion of one of Napa's biggest legends makes a name for himself in Mendocino County with Meyer Family Cellars|publisher=''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''|date=6 April 2007|accessdate=19 March 2013}} ==Background== Meyer was born Raymond Meyer on 11 November 1938 in [[Bakersfield, California]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/12/us/justin-meyer-63-winemaker-renowned-for-his-cabernet.html|title=Justin Meyer, 63, Winemaker Renowned for His Cabernet|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|accessdate=26 March 2013}} Just out of high school, he became a monk of the Christian Brothers, and changed his first name to Justin. He taught Spanish at a Christian Brothers high school in [[Sacramento]] and in 1964 was apprenticed to winemaker Brother Timothy at their winery, [[Greystone Cellars]], in [[St. Helena, California]] in the [[Napa Valley]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/aug/10/local/me-meyer10|title=Justin Meyer, 63; Founder of Napa Valley's Silver Oak Cellars|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|date=10 August 2002|accessdate=26 March 2013}} At one point the Christian Brothers ran 6 wineries and were the largest brandy producers in the world according to Meyer. ===Career=== [[File:Justin Meyer and Ray Duncan.jpg|thumb|right|Meyer with Silver Oak Cellars co-founder, [[Ray Duncan]]]] He left the Christian Brothers in 1972, and became president of V&E Consulting and Management Company.{{cite book|title=Australian Viticulture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6e1JAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=26 March 2013|year=2003|publisher=Winetitles : printed by Hyde Park Press|page=73}} That year, Meyer met Colorado entrepreneur [[Ray Duncan]] who had purchased a 750 acre plot of land in the [[Napa Valley]] of northern California, which was formerly the Oakville Dairy farm, as an investment in growing and selling grapes.{{cite book|last=Moss|first=Austin Peter|title=Cole's insiders guide to the wines & vines of Napa County|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pviE-7_jhOAC|accessdate=26 March 2013|date=March 1991|publisher=Cole Pub. Co.|isbn=978-0-929635-06-4|page=222}}{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-169026093.html|title=The cult of Cabernet: Silver Oak Cellars soars with single-minded niche.(Silver Oak Wine Cellars)(Company overview)|publisher=''[[ColoradoBiz]]'', accessed via [[HighBeam Research]]|date=1 September 2007|accessdate=26 March 2013}} Meyer, a winemaker who was a monk of the Christian Brothers religious order, formed an agreement, with Duncan, setting up a winery on the Christian Brother's site in [[St. Helena, California|St. Helena]]. Meyer would provide his winemaking, cultivation and Californian market expertise while Duncan provided the financial backing. The pair bottled their first vintage Cabernet Sauvignon in 1972, aging the wine in the old Keig Dairy barn on the original plot of land Duncan purchased.{{cite book|last1=Kushman|first1=Rick|last2=Beal|first2=Hank|title=A Moveable Thirst: Tales and Tastes from a Season in Napa Wine Country|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9tT9ufpJfsMC&pg=PA247|accessdate=26 March 2013|date=16 April 2007|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-471-79386-1|page=247}} They made the decision to produce only Cabernet Sauvignon and to attempt to produce the finest in the world,{{cite book|last1=Martin|first1=Don W.|last2=Martin|first2=Betty Woo|last3=Sebastiani|first3=Sam|title=The Best of the Wine Country|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wHmAOJmWmF0C|accessdate=26 March 2013|date=2 March 2005|publisher=DiscoverGuides|isbn=978-0-942053-43-2|page=138}}{{cite book|last=Lenkert|first=Erika|title=Frommer's Portable California Wine Country|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zX1_FyV0c3MC&pg=PA59|accessdate=26 March 2013|date=19 July 2006|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-04313-4|page=59}} to age the wine exclusively in American oak barrels.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/richard-jennings/california-cabernet_b_1572869.html|author=Jennings, Richard|title=Silver Oak: Reappraising a California Cabernet Icon |publisher=''[[Huffington Post]]''|date=6 June 2012|accessdate=26 March 2013}} Meyer said of the reason for deciding to concentrate on one wine, "it was kind of a reaction to my days at Christian Brothers, where we made so many wines it was hard to do them all right, and it was kind of in keeping with what I thought — that Cabernets were what Napa and Sonoma did best, so why not devote our attention to that. This is a pretty common concept in France." According to noted wine critic [[Robert M. Parker Jr.|Robert Parker]], Meyer always believed in harvesting ripe, physiologically mature fruit.{{cite book|last=Parker|first=Robert|title=The Wine Buyer's Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g5cV3D4B3fQC|accessdate=26 March 2013|year=1996|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|isbn=978-0-7513-0342-1|page=978}} In answer to the question of why Silver Oak insists upon aging their wines in American oak barrels, Meyer once said, "I'm happy with a cellar of about 65 degrees. Aging is speeded up by heat and slowed down by cold, but the only thing I do to modify my cellar is drink it faster... To my palate, American oak imparts less wood tannin than French oak. I like tannic wine about as much as I like tough steak."{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-68820841.html|title=Drinking in the sights, wines at Yosemite|publisher=''Daily Herald'', accessed via [[HighBeam Research]]|date=13 January 1999|accessdate=26 March 2013}} [[File:Justin Meyer3.jpg|thumb|left|Meyer and Silver Oak's barrels]] Meyer and Duncan made their first three vintages at the Christian Brothers winery, and in 1975 bought the Franciscan Winery, selling it in 1978 to buy the Silver Oak winery near [[Oakville, California|Oakville]] and buying up new land. The Silver Oak winery began production in 1981 and the 1982 harvest was considered by Meyer to be "something special" and was attempted to be replicated in later years. Growth of the company from 1977 onwards enabled Silver Oak to purchase further vineyards in the 1980s and early 1990s, becoming one of the most successful Cabernet Sauvignon brands.{{cite book|last1=Dorling|first1=Kindersley|last2=Gordon|first2=Jim|title=The Wine Opus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rtCOd5cL1gIC&pg=PA37|accessdate=26 March 2013|date=1 October 2010|publisher=Dorling Kindersley Limited|isbn=978-1-4053-5267-3|page=37}}{{cite book|title=Quarterly Review of Wines|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=50YsAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=27 February 2013|year=2005|publisher=Richard L. Elia|page=54}} By the 1994 vintage, the concept changed and the Silver Oak Napa became a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Merlot and Petit Verdot, but still aged solely in American oak, a California take on the classic Bordeaux chateau-bottled red wine.{{cite web|author=Boyd, Gerald D.|url=http://www.winereviewonline.com/Boyd_on_New_Silver_Oak_Napa.cfm|title=The "New" Silver Oak Napa|publisher=Wine Review Online|date=27 May 2009|accessdate=26 March 2013}} Meyer was President of the [[American Vineyard Foundation]] in the 1990s, and also held several other important positions in the wine industry.{{cite book|last=Perdue|first=Lewis|title=The Wrath of Grapes: The Coming Wine Industry Shakeout And How To Take Advantage Of It|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=orLMtM7zoeQC&pg=PA54|accessdate=26 March 2013|date=1 June 1999|publisher=Lewis Perdue|isbn=978-0-380-80151-0|page=54}} He breathed new life into the flailing American Vineyard Foundation from the late 1980s; ''[[Wines and Vines]]'' stated that Meyer's most important contribution will be his influence in bringing growers and winemakers together to shape the very future of California wine." He trained [[Daniel Baron]] extensively to replace himself as Silver Oak's chief winemaker. In the late 1990s, he was diagnosed with Type-2 [[Diabetes]] and a degenerative brain disease.{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-11061027.html|title=Justin Meyer|publisher=Telegraph-Herald (Dubuque), accessed via [[HighBeam Research]]|date=13 August 2002|accessdate=26 March 2013}} In January 2001, he sold his share of the company to Ray Duncan, citing health problems, but continued as a consulting winemaker until his death in August 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-70657966.html|title=Justin Meyer Sells Share Of Silver Oak Wine Cellars|publisher=''[[Wines & Vines]]'', accessed via [[HighBeam Research]]|date=1 February 2001|accessdate=26 March 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-70657966.html|title=Justin Meyer's legacy to California wine|publisher=''[[Wines & Vines]]'', accessed via [[HighBeam Research]]|date=1 November 2002|accessdate=26 March 2013}} Meyer once said "Only one wine can be your best, and I felt that cabernet was what we did best in Napa and Sonoma". ==Death and legacy== [[File:Justin Meyer4.jpg|thumb|Meyer enjoying a glass of wine]] Meyer died of a heart attack at the age of 63 while on vacation in the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] mountains near [[Lake Tahoe]] on August 6, 2002.{{cite book|title=Vineyard & Winery Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OO5IAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=26 March 2013|year=2002|publisher=Vineyard & Winery Management|page=154}} A memorial service was held at Silver Oak four days later.{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-92043544.html|title=Justin Meyer dead at 63|publisher=''[[Wines & Vines]]'', accessed via [[HighBeam Research]]|date=1 September 2002|accessdate=26 March 2013}} Upon his death, [[Jim Wolpert]], the head of the department of viticulture and enology at [[University of California Davis]] said, "The debt of gratitude that we in the research community owe to him is immeasurable. He will be missed in ways that I don't think we all understand yet. There was no question about his reputation. His approach was always a no-nonsense, no-politics approach. He never let the main issues get sidetracked." [[John De Luca]], President of the Wine Institute said "I'm not sure people truly perceive his extraordinary impact on the wine industry. He is one of the defining figures, one of the great figures in wine of our time." Patrick Gleeson, executive director of the American Vineyard Foundation, who Meyer had mentored as a young lad said, "His vision and love for wine has undoubtedly made him a living legacy amongst friends, peers and those in the industry. Justin's passing will not diminish the influence he has had on the wine industry and hopefully it will inspire others to follow in his footsteps." He is survived by his wife, Bonny. The couple had two sons, Chad and Matt, and a daughter, Holly. Bonny Meyer operates Bonny's Vineyard,{{cite book|last=Clarke|first=Oz|title=Oz Clarke's new classic wines|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vx92NjQwJVQC|accessdate=26 March 2013|date=1 October 1991|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=978-0-671-69620-7|page=125}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bonnysvineyard.com/|title=Bonny's Vineyard|publisher=Bonny's Vineyard|accessdate=26 March 2013}} and his son Matt also operates [[Meyer Family Cellars]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mfcellars.com/assets/client/File/pressrelease/family.pdf|title=Family tree is a grapevine|publisher=Mfcellars.com|accessdate=26 March 2013}} which his father helped him establish in the [[Yorkville Highlands]] of [[Mendocino County]] in January 1999. ==References== {{Commons category}} {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Meyer, Justin}} [[Category:American winemakers]] [[Category:American Christian monks]] [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:Oenologists]] [[Category:People from the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Wineries in Napa Valley]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox artist | name = Louis Paul Jonas | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Louis Paul Jonas | birth_date = {{birth date |1894|7|17|}} | birth_place = [[Budapest]], Hungary | death_date = {{death date and age |1971|2|16|1894|7|17|}} | death_place = [[Churchtown, New York]] | nationality = American | field = Sculpture | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced = | awards = }} [[File:African Hall, American Museum of Natural History (7171355207).jpg|thumb|right|African elephants in the Akeley Hall of the American Museum of Natural History]] '''Louis Paul Jonas''' (July 17, 1894 – February 16, 1971){{cite web|title=Louis Paul Jonas|url=http://www.wildlifeart.org/collection/artists/artist-louis-paul-jonas-233/|publisher=National Museum of Wildlife Art|accessdate=August 4, 2014}} was an American sculptor of [[wildlife]], [[taxidermist|taxidermist, and natural history exhibit designer]]. Born in [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]], Jonas moved to the United States at the age of 12 and went to work at his brothers' taxidermy studio, Jonas Brothers, in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver, Co]]. Later he moved to New York City, where studied under [[Carl Akeley]], a noted field naturalist, taxidermist, and animal sculptor. There, they created the [[African elephant]] group in the center of Akeley Hall at the [[American Museum of Natural History]], in New York.{{cite web|title=Jonas' Wildlife Sculpture in Big Demand|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1917&dat=19831003&id=ogshAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YXMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2739,663459|publisher=Schenectady Gazette|accessdate=August 4, 2014|pages=2|date=October 3, 1983}} Jonas opened Louis Paul Jonas Studios, Inc in [[Mahopac, New York|Mahopac, NY]],{{cite book|author1=Elliot McCreary|title=Louis Paul Jonas: He Makes Them Look Alive|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZTcEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=THE+WORLD+OF+Louis+Paul+Jonas&source=bl&ots=1YBTNIqnax&sig=eznngHhUsUwD3X-93Av2IGaebAI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=k7ffU9epFYSMyATm6oDwBQ&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=THE%20WORLD%20OF%20Louis%20Paul%20Jonas&f=false|publisher=The Rotarian|accessdate=August 4, 2014|date=October 1960}} and eventually moved to Hudson, NY. The studio was known for its miniature and full size animal sculptures, taxidermy, and natural history exhibits featured in over 50 museums worldwide.{{cite book|title=The World of Louis Paul Jonas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x1EEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86&dq=THE+WORLD+OF+Louis+Paul+Jonas&source=bl&ots=A2yG9mq419&sig=eKqaEJ4VqhiITDDLn_aX7Xdlx1w&hl=en&sa=X&ei=k7ffU9epFYSMyATm6oDwBQ&ved=0CB4Q6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=THE%20WORLD%20OF%20Louis%20Paul%20Jonas&f=false|publisher=Life Magazine|accessdate=August 4, 2014|pages=86|date=March 23, 1942}} The company created the first full sized dinosaur sculptures for the [[1964 New York World's Fair]] in the "Dinoland" area,{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160410041139/http://aoghs.org/oil-almanac/sinclair-dinosaur/|archivedate=April 10, 2016|url=http://aoghs.org/oil-almanac/sinclair-dinosaur/|title=Dinosaur Fever – Sinclair's Icon|work=Petroleum History Almanac|publisher=American Oil & Gas Historical Society |location=Washington, D.C.|year=2016|accessdate=July 2, 2016}}{{cite web|publisher=Frank J. Leskovitz|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305024647/http://gombessa.tripod.com/scienceleadstheway/id32.html|archivedate=March 5, 2016|url=http://gombessa.tripod.com/scienceleadstheway/id32.html|title=Sinclair Dinoland: New York World's Fair 1964–65|work=Science Leads the Way|year=2016|accessdate=July 2, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Ankylosaurus at HMNS: 40 Year Mystery Solved|url=http://blog.hmns.org/2009/04/ankylosaurus-at-hmns-40-year-mystery-solved/|publisher=Houston Museum of Natural Science|accessdate=August 4, 2014}} which was sponsored by the [[Sinclair Oil Corporation]].{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150509070928/https://www.sinclairoil.com/history/worlds_fair_01.html|archivedate=May 9, 2015|url=https://www.sinclairoil.com/history/worlds_fair_01.html|title=Sinclair's New York World's Fair (1964–65) "Dinoland" Pavilion|work=Sinclair History|year=2013|publisher=[[Sinclair Oil Corporation]]|accessdate=July 11, 2016}} Jonas consulted with noted paleontologists [[Barnum Brown]], [[Edwin H. Colbert]] and [[John Ostrom]] in order to create sculptures that were as accurate as possible. After the Fair closed, the dinosaur models toured the country on special flatbed trailers as part of a company advertising campaign.{{cite web|title=Sinclair at the New York World's Fair |work=1960s |url=https://www.sinclairoil.com/history/1960.html |publisher=Sinclair Oil Corporationl |accessdate=July 5, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505133148/https://www.sinclairoil.com/history/1960.html |archivedate=May 5, 2016 |df= }} Many of the statues are now on display at various museums and parks ==Sculptures on display== In 1932, Louis Paul Jonas and his brothers created the taxidermy model of the famous Australian race horse [[Phar Lap]] that is now on display at the [[Melbourne Museum]].{{cite web|title=Phar Lap at the Museum|url=http://museumvictoria.com.au/pharlap/museum/index.asp|publisher=Museum Victoria Australia|accessdate=August 5, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Phar Lap and
